editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Sir Barnaby Whigg: OR, No Wit like a WOMANS. A COMEDY. AS IT IS Acted by their MAJESTIES SERVANTS AT THE Theatre-Royal.

l.hi: Quiquid agunt homines, votum, timor, Ira, voluptas,
Gaudia, diſcurſus noſtri farrago libelli eſt.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by A. G. and J. P. for Joſeph Hindmarſh, at the Black Bull in Cornhil. 1681.

div.head: To the Right Honourable GEORGE Earl of Berkeley, Viſcount Durſely, Lord Berkeley of Berkeley-Caſtle, &c.
div.p: IT was one of the moſt prudent Actions of Virgil's Life, to beſtow the fruits of his admired Genius, and proſtrate the Labours of his Honoured Muſe at the feet of a more Honoured, Witty, and Learned Patron; for Mecaenas was a Man of an unbiaſs'd, impartial, and generous nature; and knew as well how to Judge and Applaud an Excellent Poem, as the Poet himſelf knew how to write what was fit to be Applauded.

This therefore cauſes our Modern Authors (inſtructed by his Wife Example) to make an humble offering of their Works to the moſt deſerving and knowing Men of the Age; cunningly implying, That as they have moſt Wit and Judgment to find out their faults, they have alſo moſt modeſty and good nature to excuſe 'em.

Amongſt this tribe, my Lord, I muſt humbly confeſs my ſelf one, and acknowledge theſe two Reaſons for my preſumption: Firſt, A ſecret pride to have my Play grac'd with the great Name of the Honoured Berkeley, lineally deſcended (for many Ages paſt) from the Royal Blood of the Illuſtrious Harding; and thence flowing through the veins of One and twenty Noble Families, to the Honours he now deſervedly wears, and which his Sacred Majeſty could not more juſtly beſtow. And, ſecondly, to be impartially Judg'd, by a perſon who knows as well how to write, as to • atronize.

Your Lordſhip did me once the favour to preſent me a little book of your own Writing, Entituled, Hiſtorical Applications, &c. where he that reads may find an exact ſerenity of Fancy, a vivacity of Wit, a refin'd Elegance in Language, and obſerve it to be adorn'd with certain Jems of Morality and Divinity, and other maxims of Rational Wiſdom, and true Collections of Hiſtory, that render it a piece fit to be admired by the moſt Wife and Learned, and lov'd by the moſt Religious and Loyal.

I make this little digreſſion my Lord, not out of any inſolent belief, that I am fit to commend either the Book, or its Author, for that belongs to a far better Genius and Pen, but only out of an impatient deſire to do my ſelf Juſtice in applauding you, though 'tis impoſſible I ſhould do you any.

Sola virtus vera Nobilitas, is a Maxim in which Seneca and your Lordſhip fully agree; for would any man be Pious and Morally good, let him make you his pattern; would he be bleſs'd with a ſweet, benign, and modeſt diſpoſition, and ſhow a perfect Character of true Nobility, unſway'd by the powerful vices, Pride and Folly, let him make you his pattern; Or would he be loyal and honeſt, a faithful lover of his King, and an unmovable Pillar of his Country, ſtill let him Copy you, and make your Actions his Examples, you that had rather be Juſt than Popular; and had rather follow the dictates of a good conſcience, than gain the ſervice and applauſe of a numerous and potent party.

This, my Lord, is ſo great and undoubted a Truth, that with the moſt nice apprehenſions 'tis impoſſible it ſhould leave the leaſt impreſſion of flattery; that being a thing as difficult for me to do, as for you to endure; for all that know ye will ſay thus much; and therefore 'tis probable all that love ye will ſpeak much more.

As to this Comedy, it had the Honour to pleaſe one party; and I am only glad, that the St. Georges of Eighty-one got a Victory over the old hiſſing Dragons of Forty-two; 'tis a good Omen, and I hope portends future ſucceſſes, though ſome fat Whiggs of Sir Barnaby's tribe made all the intereſt they could to cry it down.

My Lord, 'tis not only a nice, but a very difficult thing to write a good Comedy, and therefore a tolerable one ſhould be the more excuſable; for there is not only Wit, but Plot, Invention, and a quick and ingenious fancy requir'd: Fancy! the brighteſt Jewel of Poetry, of which the Famous Engliſh Spencer was the great and only Maſter,
as we may ſee in all his Deſcriptions, but more particularly in his Legend of Temperance, when he ſpeaks of Mammon or Covetouſneſs.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: At laſt he came into a gloomy Glade,
Cover'd with Bows and Shrubs from Heavens light;
Whereas he ſitting, found in ſecret ſhade,
And uncouth ſalvage and uncivil wight;
Of greizly heiw, and fowl ill-favour'd ſight,
His Head and Beard with Soot were ill bedight.
His Cole black hands did ſeem to have bin ſear'd
In Smiths fire, ſpitting forge, and nails like Claws appear'd.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: And round about him lay, on every ſide,
Great heaps of Gold, that never could be ſpent;
Of which ſome were rude Ore not purified
Of Mulciber's devouring Element.
Some others were new driven, and diſtent
Into great Ingots, and to Wedges ſquare;
Some in round Plates withouten Monument.
But moſt were ſtampt, and in their Mettal bare,
The antick ſhapes of Kings and Kezars ſtrange and rare.

div.p:
But this is a ſort of Poetry of a different nature from Dramaticks; and therefore the fancy muſt of neceſſity vary, becauſe in one it is digeſted into Characters, that are to ſpeak before a carping Audience: and in the other, perhaps, only to be read or ſpoken of before one or two perſons. But ſuppoſe the fancy to be good, that will not now ſerve turn; for in this Age 'tis not a Poets Merit, but his Party that muſt do his buſineſs; ſo that if his Play conſiſts of a Witch, a Devil, or a Broomſtick, ſo he have but a Prieſt at one end of the Play, and a Faction at 'tother end of the Pit, it ſhall be fam'd for an excellent piece. And the Mobile either encouraged by their Grandees, or treated by the Poet, ſhall throng to it with as much zeal, as they once
did to the Committee, when the ſcale was turn'd, and Loyalty began to come in faſhion.

This, my Lord, is the World, and the Worlds Nature; but you, I may boldly ſay, value Merit for its own ſake, and not through intereſt, or to pleaſe a faction, you will not hiſs or clap a Play in the wrong place, nor uſe an Arbitrary Power to carry a Cauſe by Popular Interest or Parties: I ſay you will not do this, and I wiſh all others were of your mind. But ſince they are not, your Lordſhips acceptance and patronizing of this Comedy, is the greateſt Encouragement and Honour that can poſſibly happen to,

closer.signed: Your Lordſhips obliged and devoted humble Servant, THO. DURFEY.

lg.l: HOW long, alas! muſt our unhappy Stage
Groan for the follies of this Plotting Age?
When ſhall our doubts and anxious fears have end,
That we may once more know a foe from friend?
Once more of Truth and Honeſty make tryal,
And not be Villains thought, for being Loyal.
When ſhall we ſee an Audience in the Pit,
Not ſway'd by Factions, that will ſilent ſit,
And friends to th' Poet, calmly judge his Wit?
Or when a Noble, Royal Party view,
That dare to mighty Caeſar give his due,
Spite of the Numerous, Buzzing, Crop-ear'd Crew?
When theſe things happen, we ſhall calm our fears;
But no ſuch bleſſing in theſe times appears.
Diſtraction rages now, and th' frantick Town,
Plagu'd with Sham-plots, a very Bedlam's grown.
Like Lunaticks ye roar and range about;
Frame Plots, then crack your brains to find 'em out;
Like Oliver's Porter, but not ſo devout.
Our City-friends too, that o're Coffee droop,
For fear the French ſhould come and eat 'em up.
Brumicham-Proteſtants, that rail and grieve ye,
With names of Maſquerader and Tantivy:
That, Plagu'd with natural and ſubtil fears,
Think all the Loyal Party Dogs and Bears,
Run mad with Pious Zeal for th' good o' th' Nation,
And how to fix a godly Reformation.
Since then from theſe he ne're can hope ſucceſs,
To you th' Impartial Judges of Wits Caſe,
The Poet humbly offers his Addreſs.
With you his fate's ſecure, and doubly bleſt;
Apollo's Synod all; and for the reſt,
That he ſhall know both Parties, now he Glories;
By Hiſſes th' Whiggs, and by their Claps the Tories.

list.item: Wilding. — A Loyal and Witty Gentleman, only addicted to rail againſt Women. BY Mr. Clark.
Townly. — A Modiſh inconſtant young fellow, in Love with, and beloved by all Women, and courts all alike. BY Mr. Goodman.
Sir Wal. Wiſeacre. — An Opinionated Fool and Cuckold: A Lancaſhire-Knight, and in Love with Livia. BY Mr. Jermaine.
Capt. Porpuſs. — A blunt Tarpawlin, Captain, and one that uſes his Sea-phraſes and terms upon all occaſions. BY Mr. Griffin.
Sir Barn. Whigg. — A Phanatical Raſcal, one of Oliver's Knights; one that always pretends to fear a change of Government yet does his beſt to cauſe one. BY Mr. Powell.
Benedick. — An Intriguer, and Friend to Wilding. BY Mr. Perin.
Swift. — Servant to Wilding. BY Mr. Coſh.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: Gratiana. — Witty and proud, and one that values her ſelf by railing againſt men. BY Mrs. Corbet.
Livia. — Wife to Porpuſs, cunning and wanton, and in love with Townly. BY Mrs. Cook.
Millicent. — Wife to Sir Walter, in Love alſo with Townly. BY Mrs. Moyle.
Winifrid. — A young Welſh Jilt. BY Mrs. Percival.
Waiters, Men and Women, Muſicians, Officers and Attendants.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Wilding, Captain Porpuſs, Benedick, Townly, Gratiana, Millicent, Livia, Winiford juſt ending a Dance.
A Table, Bottles and Cards ready.

sp.speaker: Wilding.
sp.p: SO, Madam, now the courſe is finiſh'd, and your ſqueaking Inſtruments are ſilent; I hope a man may have the priviledge to retire and fan himſelf a little. To Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: Yes, and I believe without danger of a ſecond engagement, unleſs you could promiſe more skill than you have ſhewn hitherto.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Nay Tom, for ſhame deſert not ſo beautiful a Partner ſo ſoon.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Not Deſert her! Gad he that catches me cutting a Caper agen, I'le give him leave to cut a leg off, that I may have a maim to remember my folly by.
sp.stage: The Captain is courting Winifrid all this while.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: If you were to be maim'd for every folly you committed, I queſtion whether you could find your fellow Cripple in any Hoſpital in Town.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: So, there's one full hit, pray Heav'n, my friend have skill enough to defend himſelf.

sp.speaker: Millic.
sp.p: Perhaps, Madam, Mr. Wilding (like an excellent Singer) thinks 'tis becomming to undervalue his perfection: Pray, Sir, be real: Do you not love Dancing?
sp.stage: Townly is Courting Livia this while.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Love it! oh extremely in a cold froſty morning, when a man has been at a true Debauch the night before: I hold it to be the only neceſſary Diverſion: Dancing, Madam! why 'tis the very glowing-brand of Luxury that kindles the temperate blood, heats and fires us till we are fit for the Modiſh buſineſs 'twas deſign'd for: Then think not but I doat on it moſt violently.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Pox on him, now ſhall we have no more Dancing to night.

sp.speaker: Millic.
sp.p: We Women find it otherwiſe; therefore value little what you think of it.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Think of it! why, Madam, to think, is contrary to thoſe of his Complexion: I dare ſwear for the Gentleman, he ſeldom thinks of any thing, unleſs it be how to excuſe his being ſecond in a Duel. Come, prithee come away, he's pumping for a Repartee I warrant: but it ſhall not do Sir.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; Why how now friend?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A commixture of pride, wantonneſs, and affectation handſomly bound up together: Prithee what is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: You ſhall know that anon: but ſee! yonders Jack Townly courting the Captain's Lady, and the Old Tar-pawling, I think, is making tenders to my little Welſh Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The Autumn of Luſt, and the blooming ſpring of Folly met in deſpite of nature.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: In deſpight of it indeed; but the comfort is, it cannot laſt long.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, 'tis only ſuperficial, and extends to thought, foppery in expreſſion; but no further: An old mans Love is like Snow in Summer, always unnatural; and no ſooner is, but it is not; the frigid nature of the one, not agreeing with the kindly warmth of to'ther.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Once! I tell thee I do love thee: To Winifrid. by Mars I do; Prithee furl thy Sails and let me view thee a little; I have no fine phraſes, but by Boreas I affect thee heartily, thy face, thy leg, thy ſhape, thy every thing: When wilt thou come to the Tower, and let me ſalute thee with the great Guns — hah? Bounce, bounce, bounce, thou ſhalt have Royal ſport my Girl.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: I pray you Captains, of all Loves, no more of theſe creat 'ordes and noiſes; for look you, her has put a poor weak prains, and never apide creat Cuns, nor Pounce, pounce, pounce, her cannot apide pounces, look you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Cannot her apide pounces! why her ſall have Muſicks, and Junkits, and Dances then, if her cannot apide pounces: the Kettle-Drums and Trumpets ſhall Divert thee, my little Juno: the Eagle ſhall clap her Wings in ſign of joy, and the Royal Lyon ſhall Roar thee welcome.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Pleſs us awl, are you mads? if her hears Lyons, her is dead: the ferq and pictures of Lyons makes her ſwoon'd, her eyes cloſe, and her breath Ferk, ferk, ferk, in her pelly with fits of Mothers and Fathers: I believe in my Conſcience, look you, the Captain's is diſtractious: A Lyons! pleſs us awl, her cannot apide the name on't.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Cads plut, her cannot abide nothing, I think: Put does her preaths and her pelly's Ferk, ferk, ferk ſo much, does her ſay?

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Piſh, this is Simplicity's, look you, and Impertinencies. I pray you forbear, Captains.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Diddle, Diddle, Diddle, ſhe has a Tongue as glib as an Eel; but no matter, ſhe is Amſterdam built, and by Mars I love her for her Dutch Bottom.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Look! he has frighted her away already: I'le warrant there has bin an excellent Harangue betwixt 'em.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Blunt to ſome purpoſe, without doubt; but I believe very ſavoury, and full of good meaning.

div.stage: Enter Sir Walter with Bottles in his hands, and a Girdle hung round with Bottles.
The Ladies go to a Table as deſigning to play at Cards, only Livia ſtays with Townly.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Hey ſcowr, ſcowr my lads, and now for a Health-Royal; ſo here my Jolly hearts, Wat is return'd in triumph; view me round boys, honeſt Watt has been ſcowring for you: Watt muſt have a Health-Royal ere we part, faith: Hey, bring a Dozen of Glaſſes there.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well, ſaid Sir Walter Wiſeacre, gad we thought you had left us.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Left thee! what before thou wert Drunk, Bully-Rock? Prithee don't think me ſuch an unnatural Rogue to leave thee in a ſneaking, ſober condition: So, ho! where's this fellow? I was delay'd below by a Damn'd Raſcal the Clerk of the Pariſh that came to me, Sir, for Church-duties; and I think I have paid him, for I took him into the Cellar, Drunk ſix pint Bumpers, a Health-Royal to him, tript up his heels with bonny Puntack, and left the Rogue ſinging Pſalms under a Pipe of Malaga.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why God-a-mercy Clerk, y' ſaith, and yet, Sir Walter, I ſee you are freſh ſtill?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Freſh! not concern'd I: freſh as the morning, and as gay as the ſpring; ah! I can Drink like a fiſh man, and hold like a Kilderkin: but, come my lads, chuſe, chuſe — what Wine you like? this is Champaign, and this is Burgundy, this Obrion, this Puntack; and here's a deer Bottle of Cohorſe that exceeds all.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: There's a fine name now to put off pall'd Claret, and cheat the ſubject with.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Cohorſe! a Pox o' theſe barbarous notions, why 'tis all but Claret ſtill, and only the Vintners cheat to extort a ſhilling in a Pottle upon account of the Prohibition.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Prohibition! peace old Water Rat; peace I ſay, thou canſt not fathom my depth old Plummet; for you muſt know, Sir, that I deal with an honeſt, civil perſon, and great friend of the Governours of — no matter where: Well, Sir, he upon occaſion has ſore eyes: Wines come Incognito; my friend breaks the Law, cheats the King, ſteals Cuſtom, ſells me a lumping penniworth; and, prithee, what ſignifies the Prohibition? but come, every one his Bottle, and a Health-Royal I muſt make you all Drunk: you know my way.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Tis not convenient to begin a match of Drinking in the Ladies company, Sir Walter?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Gad that's true, eſpecially before my Miſtreſs too; Come then, let's drink a civil glaſs, and retire to the next Room. Captain Porpuſs, here old Spunge, thou art a man of a ſound brain; Come, here's your Ladies Health.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Not mine, good Sir Knight; begin your own Ladies, we have not had that to night.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: My Wives, Sir I'de have you know I'le have no ſuch plebeian conjugal Cuſtoms in my houſe; beſides 'twill pall the Wine, and give an unſavoury reliſh to my mouth all the night after.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: The pallat that's always out of taſte, has no occaſion to be made more inſipid; and your cuſtoms, Sir (like your Counſel) are often too ſhallow to be very taking.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Here, here, take this Bumper; prithee let me make thee Drunk, that I may once ſee thee in a good humour; ah that ſhe were gone once, that I might be Jocoſe, and break a Jeſt or two with my deer Miſtriſs there. Pointing to Livia, whom Townly is talking with.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir, I'le have no whiſpering here by Mars; I ſhall lay you ſhort by the Mizzen, if you think to grapple my Pinnace: therefore, hands off, this, Sir, is my Wife, and this is my Sword; my name is Captain Porpuſs, I drink Claret, and therefore ſhould Diſpute as well as ſhe, Sir: Come, ſtate your Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: What queſtion, Sir? — Plague of his Interruption. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What queſtion, Sir? why a Mathematical queſtion, terms of Navigation, Card, Compaſs, Lading, any thing; Come, what a Devil have you ſeen of the World, Sir? I have ſtood and fac'd both frigid and torrid Zones, plough'd up the Boſphorus like a Molehill, kindled a Torch in the Sun, ſhot both the Gulfs of Venice and Florida, and ſeen the Navel of the World, you Scoundrel.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, a pleaſant humour, y' faith.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Prithee Captain leave this bluſtering: Gad thou haſt got ſo many Damn'd, cramp, hard Sea-words, they are enough to fright an honeſt Country Gentleman out of the Company.

sp.speaker: Millic.
sp.p: Madam we want ye to make one at Looe.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: A Tarpawlin, a rude Sea-fellow, you muſt not mind him man; but, dear Jack, doſt thou remember what I told thee to day concerning my Wife?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Very well Sir; but faith I wiſh you would chuſe ſome other man, for my modeſty is always ſo offenfive if I am to ſpeak to a Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Modeſty! alas poor fellow: I'le tell thee what I'le do then, I'le make thee Drunk; prithee let me, I love it, I delight in't man: I make a dozen or two Drunk every day; get but Drunk, and then Boy, never doubt thy confidence; for a Collegian once intoxicated, is the moſt impudent creature that ever I met with.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: And are not you then guilty of a great Imprudence to truſt me with your Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Not at all man, not a Jot; for though to me ſhe be pall'd, nay to my grief a Wife all over; yet, Pox on't, I know ſhe's honeſt, for ſhe's a great Churchwoman.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: A Churchwoman!

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Never the honeſter for that, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Sir Wa • t.
sp.p: Alas, poor ſoul, ſhe prays continually; and as for her Virtue, ſhe keeps that ſecure, cloſe ſhut up in a Purſe; the great Devil, her pride, pulling at one ſtring, and Doctor Tickle-text the to'ther.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you may command my ſervice in any thing. Was ever ſuch a Coxcomb?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Peace, not a word more, we are obſerv'd. — Come, a Song there: What ſay'ſt thou, Captain? Do'ſt love a Song?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ay, a Battel, a Siege, a Storm, or ſo: Sing a Song that has ſome ſenſe in't, and perhaps I may condeſcend to bear a Bob my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Nay, then we ſhall have charming-ſtuff.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: We have not had a good bold well-ſeaſon'd Song, as Gad ſave me, ſince Old Broom dy'd: 'Woon's we can get nothing now-a-days but Phillis and Chloris, and Celia, and the 'tother Whore in the Strand, that was kept by 'tother Fop, ſo long, till at laſt ſhe was forc'd to keep him, Gads bud: Why now a Storm, a Sea-fight, or ſuch a Song wou'd delight a man. — Sbud there's both Body and Soul in't; and a Pox on Phillis and Chloris, they were both Strumpets, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Friend farewell, my patience is outworn, and I muſt begone, I am like a fiſh out of the water; methinks I gaſp for breath, and grow ſick by being ſo long out of my Element.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Nay, faith, you muſt not ſtir without me.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I ſhall never forget a frolick we had about Twelve years ago: I was then Captain of the Succeſs, Heav'n bleſs her, ſhe was a brave Ship: ah how ſhe wou'd ſcud in the Winds Eye, and have made the Sea foam again after a Broadſide: by Mars I never think of her loſs, but the pearly Dew falls from my Eyes.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Ha, ha, this is ridiculous enough.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: To think what a Fighter ſhe was; how ſhe wou'd ſpoom along; top-ſails a trip; and then the beſt Saylor in the World: 'tis a ſtrange thing, Gentlemen, I have known that Ship ſail tightly when ſhe has had above Forty Culvering Bullets in her; all ſhot through betwixt Wind and Water.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How, how Sir! betwixt Wind and Water?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: All betwixt Wind and Water, as Gad ſave me: Ah you are Pilchers to me in Sea-affairs: Well, ſhe was riding at Soll-Bay, 'twas juſt before the ſight there (wherein I did ſuch notable ſervice); I had then a Lieutenant aboard, a little Dapper fellow, but as ſtout as Hercules; and when we met a nights in the great Cabbin over a Jolly bowl of Punch, the Rogue wou'd ſing us the fineſt Sea-Songs, and ſo Roar 'em out: I think I've a fellow can remember one of them. Sing ſirrha.

lg.l: BLow Boreas, blow, and let thy ſurly Winds
Make the Billows foam and roar:
Thou canſt no Terror breed in Valiant minds,
But ſpite of thee we'll live and find the ſhore:
Then cheer my heart, and be not aw'd,
But keep the Gun-Room clear,
Though Hell's broke looſe, and the Devils roar abroad;
Whilſt we have Sea-room here boys, never fear:
Hey, how ſhe toſſes up, how far!
The mounting Top-maſt toucht a Star:
The Meteors blaz'd as through the Clouds we came,
And Salamander-like we live in Flame.
But now we ſink, now, now we go
Down to the deepeſt ſhades below.
Alas! where are we now? who, who can tell,
Sure 'tis the loweſt Room of Hell,
Or where the Sea-gods dwell?
With them we'l live, with them we'l live and raign;
With them we'l laugh and ſing, and drink amain:
But ſee we mount, ſee, ſee we riſe again.
Though flaſhes of lightning and tempeſts of rain
Do fiercely comend which ſhall conquer the Main;
Though the Captain do's ſwear, inſtead of a Prayer,
And the Sea is all fired by the Demons of the Air:
We'l drink and defie, the mad ſpirits that fly,
From the deep to the skie,
And ſing whilſt the Thunder do's bellow;
For Fate ſtill will have a kind fate for the brave,
And nere make his grave of a ſalt water Wave;
To drown, drown, never to drown;
No, never to drown a good fellow.

sp.p: There now! there's life, there's ſoul, there's ſenſe: as I'm a living man, Gentlemen, the Rogue fox'd me three times, one after another, only by ſinging this Song.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Now, Madam, your Ladyſhip owes me fifteen.
sp.stage: The Ladies are all this while at the Table playing at Cards.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: But five indeed, Madam, your Ladyſhip was Loo'd laſt Deal upon my Blaze.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Madam, 'twas my Cozen here.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Upon my Souls, look you, her is not Loo'd; her had the good Kings guarded, and won two or three tricks indeed.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Nay, prithee do not wrangle, I ſwear thou art the worſt player at Cards.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Heav'n deliver my Souls! is her diſtractious? was not her fluſhes of Clubs upon her laſt Deal? beſides a Mournivals of Queens, and another of Knaves, for thirty Counters, beſides the fifteen her Ladyſhip ow'd her? What does her Ladyſhip think her will loſe thirty Counters, look you?

sp.speaker: Millic.
sp.p: By no means — but pray let us give over now, for my part I am tyr'd.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And I faith.

sp.speaker: Millic.
sp.p: Come Ladies, there's very good Wall fruit in the Garden, pray let's take a turn or two.
sp.stage: Exeunt all but Wilding, Sir Walter Benedick.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Now follow her Jack now; dear Jack, this is a rare opportunity.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: This is an odd humour, faith, what intreat Townly to follow his Wife?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: There is ſomething more in it than I underſtand, but the fool is leaky as a Sieve; I am ſure he can keep no ſecrets, we ſhall know all.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Come, my hearts, 'tother dozen Bottles, and then we ſhall be fit for the buſineſs of the night; Pox on't, 'tis ſo long ſince I was Drunk, that I'm as dull as a Country Student, poring upon Littleton; Hey boy, bring the Wine there.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why you have ſpoil'd the Drinking-match, Sir Walter, by letting Jack Townly go.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Ay, he's ſo true a Son of Bacchus, he'l do every one Reaſon, Gad I'le go fetch him back.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Gad but you ſhall not though, by your favour, for to my knowledge he's buſie; he's engag'd with my Wife.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ingag'd with her! what a Devil does the fool mean?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: What! ſome Plot or other now I warrant: here's ſome Intrigue going forward, in which he is to be Agent: What an unnatural Rogue art thou to keep this from thy friends? Come, come, Diſcover.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Why then, the truth is, I have an excellent deſign on foot, but 'tis impoſſible you ſhould fathom any thing of it, unleſs you were better acquainted with with my humours.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Humours! why, prethee, what are thy Humours?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Why, you muſt know, Sir, that I am famous over the Town for two topping humours: look you; for making people Drunk, that's one; and making Cuckolds, that's another.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Two very pretty topping humours, faith.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: You know 'tis faſhionable for a man to be famous for ſomething; beſides, I have the beſt Diverſion in the world by it, for they reach to all qualities and conſtitutions; for if I meet with a young modiſh Fop, there I pleaſe one of my humours, and make him Drunk: If with a ſober, grave, judicious, married Coxcomb, then I pleaſe my 'tother humour.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: And lye with his Wife? —

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: I do ſo; I do y' faith, is't not fine? this laſt has been my humour many years.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: If I had a mortal averſion to Women, I could never think 'em ſo notorious to conſent to this.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Pox, a lye's as natural to him as Nonſenſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Come, y' are both my friends, and I think I may truſt you with my ſecret: know then, that at this inſtant I have a violent paſſion for a Lady, another mans wife.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: So, I knew we ſhould have it. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: But as the Devil wou'd have it, Jealouſie, that Canker of Wedlock, that Aquafortis of Matrimony, that eats and eats ſo damnably, till it hath devour'd all the love betwixt man and wife; incites, Sir, my plaguy Spouſe juſt in the nick to interpoſe betwixt me and my deſign.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Gad that was very unlucky indeed, eſpecially in ſuch a juncture.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Juncture! — nay we had joyn'd, and joyn'd agen long before this, if it had not bin for that man: Now, Sir, I had no way to help my ſelf, but by having Recourſe to my cunning; and, by the way, let me tell you, Gentlemen, I do poſitively believe I am the moſt cunning perſon that ever breath'd: — I ſhould ha' made a ſwinging Politician if I had but a Memory.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Your large ear and wry noſe always ſignifie thought, Sir Walter.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: For thinks I to my ſelf, Love will root out love, and Company often diverts Jealouſie; and if I could oblige ſome young and honeſt friend, who by pretending love to her, would amuſe her a little; I might proſperouſly carry on my Intrigue abroad, and ſhe be diverted, and reſt very well ſatisfied at home.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: So that you would expoſe your own Wife to the Addreſſes of ſome young Gallant, that you your ſelf might have liberty to Debauch another mans?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Ay I wou'd ſo; Is't not a good one? and may I never more warm me by thoſe fair eyes I ſo adore, if this ſpring clearly from my own natural wit, my own invention by this light? Is't not an odd method?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ay, the Devil take me, is it as ever I heard of.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Well, after a great deal of conſultation whom to truſt in ſo weighty a buſineſs, I pitch'd upon Townly, but with a great deal of caution firſt; for, Jack (ſays I) have a great care Jack of handling Caſes about my Wife that does not concern you: — Yes, ſays Jack, demurely: (you know his way). And agen, ſaid I, Jack be ſure that you are not too forward in preſſing my Wives conſtitution beyond her fidelity; no, ſays Jack, agen with a great deal of integrity, before Gad.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Is Townly a modeſt fellow, or does he only wheedle this fool?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Modeſt! Pox on him, I knew a Surgeon that cur'd him of two Claps when he was at Cambridge.
sp.stage: Gratiana and Livia return, and walk over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Uds ſo, here are the Ladies! I muſt wait on 'em home; Dear ſouls, you muſt pardon me, and have a little patience, I muſt be civil to the Ladies: he little thinks the Captain's Lady here is the Perſon I adore ſo much. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Sir, I have a Coach at the door, and ſhall need no Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Nay you ſhall be both Drunk long enough before night, I warrant you: you know my humour, Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Ay, enough of it to know thee for a damn'd Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And Cuckhold; I hope by this time, or Townly's an Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: The Rogue is as conceited as a Dancing-Maſter; and though he be the Vulcan of ſenſe, yet thinks himſelf the Apollo of it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I have ever obſerv'd, 'tis as impoſſible for an affected perſon to be a man of wit, as for a mercenary Bawd to turn honeſt.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Or a good Poet to be Religious.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo; but, prithee, what is that prink'd-up creature that went out with Livia juſt now?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Oh I was about to tell thee before; She's my Lord Lofty's Daughter, a rich Heireſs, Tom, and a vaſt fortune, and one that fantaſtically loves to rail at men, as much as thou doſt at women: you two would make an excellent match; faith I'd have thee go and court her.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I would, if I thought my words could have influence enough upon her to make her hate her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: What a ſtrange humour thou art of; becauſe one woman was falſe and jilted thee, is it infallible that the whole Sex are ſo?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The whole Sex, by Heav'n (if you love 'em): beſides, the paſſion it ſelf is fooliſh and unmanly: Love is the ſickneſs of the mind; a man has his Ague and Feaver both at once, and often deſpairs of remedy for either.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Thus like a ſick man you think no Dyet good, becauſe your Stomach's naught: Well, I thank my Stars, the conſtitution differs with me; I can diſtinguiſh the great bleſſing of mans life, and in a pious zeal thank Providence for its bounty. Beautiful Women were ever my Tutelar and Guardian Angels, that give me an aſſurance of being ever happy in this world, and immortal in t'other.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A Coxcomb in t'other.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Prithee no more of this; a young brisk fellow, newly an Heir too, and Poſſeſſor of a plentiful Eſtate, whoſe good old Father was ſo gratefully civil, to dye orderly, and in good time, that thou might'ſt inherit, to ſtand at defiance with the only bleſſing of life, Women: I am aſham'd of thee.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: 'Twould be more advantage to thee to be aſham'd of thy Miſtreſs; for if thou art not jilted, I am miſtaken in her; She'l ſhew thee a Welſh trick ſometime or other.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Oh, I'le venture that: hark 'e, wilt thou go with me, and ſpeak to this Lady?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: She that went hence now.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Ay, I'd have thee rally her a little.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well Sir, I'le give her a hearing, if ſhe be not too impertinent.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Come on then, I'le introduce thee.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How now! what noiſe is that below, ſirrha?

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: Sir Barnaby Whigg, Sir, has been railing againſt his Nephew, Sir Walter, for having ne'r a Musquet in's houſe.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Whigg is his name? Oh, I believe I know him, a huge fat fellow, one of Oliver's Knights.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The ſame, and the moſt buſie, ſeditious Coxcomb alive, one that will be ſure to Bet when he ſees the beſt Trump, but ever ſhuffle and cheat, if fortune be againſt him.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: In all turns of State, change his Opinion as eaſily as his Coat, and is ever zealous in Voting for that party that is moſt Powerful.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: They of his Tribe ſay, theirs is the Church-Militant; but I ſay Money is both their God and King, and the greateſt Zealot amongſt them for the ſake of the Popes Golden Slipper, ſhall not only kiſs his Toe, but eat it, as the ſtory goes of the hungry Spaniel.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: If I miſtake not, this fellow values himſelf extremely by playing on the Muſick.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh yes, but the Town of late has us'd him ſo unkindly, that he has left it off, and now ſets up for a grand Politician.

sp.speaker: Sir Barnab.
sp.p: A care •… ſs Villain — he ſhall not own the blood of the Whiggs that neglects his Countrey thus: — ne'r a Muſquet a Rogue — in this Popiſh Age too, and but one Sword, na • , and in a family of ſixteen People upriſing and down-lying — a Dog — a Raſcal — but one Sword?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Now Sir Barnaby, pray why this anger?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: There's reaſon for't, Sir, as times go: how does your good Father, or rather your good Mother, Mr. Wilding? her zeal did once fructifie and increaſe, to my knowledge: Come, ſhe was a good Woman — a Son of a Whore, ne'r a Dagger neither, nor a Caſe-knife ſharp at end — nor nothing — not ſo much as a Pen-knife?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: You ſeem diſturb'd, Sir, pray what news abroad?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Only we are loſt, undone; that's all Sir; and (like faggots) the bands of zeal being broken, muſt fall hudling to deſtruction — a Pox upon him, ne'r a Muſquet?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How, to Deſtruction, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Come, come, things go ill, Mr. Wilding, things go ill; you have not Bulk enough to bear State-matters, or elſe I could tell you in your ear that — how do you rate this Beaver, good Mr. — a —?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: At a friends acceptance, Sir: have you a mind to't?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: No, no, not I by no means, not I: the Hat's well made though: I knew your Father long ago, Mr. Wilding; he was always a free, generous ſoul indeed — but (betwixt you and I) would not be rul'd: he would ſtill be on the wrong ſide: Come, come, he lov'd the King too well; had he not lov'd the King, he had been a brave fellow.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Otherwiſe called a Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Come Sir, you are all miſ-led, and will be all pickled ere long; I can tell you, that if our ſoul-ſaving Party do not ſettle the Nation, I ſay 'twill track, 'twill unhinge — whip you 're gen, old Antichriſt will have your Lands and Bodies, and the Devil your Souls.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Your ſoul, I hope, will be in no great danger however, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: No, not mine, I never carry mine about me: mine's always in the heart of the City — in Lumbard ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: The Rogue has once in his life ſpoke truth.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Incorrigible Villain! but I have made an Obſervation, That Fanaticiſm Intoxicates like Wine, and has much the ſame effects: For as a true Drunkard cannot keep a ſecret, but muſt make ſome diſcovery, ſo your true Presbyter never talks of State-affairs without a Tang of Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: I was yeſterday with an Aſtrologer, a learned man, and one of our Tribe, and (Lord bleſs us) he tells me we ſhall have a Famine.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: A Famine! why, that's worſe to you than Damnation.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo, as Gad ſave me, I ſwoon'd away twice at the very apprehenſion on't; and had not a Suppoſe brought me ſome comfort, on my Conſcience, had dyed: A Famine! Mercy on us; Come War, Peſtilence, Fire, Sword, any thing but that; the Gut-Plague is ſure more terrible than all thoſe of Egypt.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: This Epicure I ſee never conſiders life any further than the pleaſure of eating and drinking.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Were matters carried well, we ſhould have none of this; no Meteors, nor Comets, nor Peſtilences, were not our ſins Contagious; were faith and frugallity among us, no hungry Tuſcany-Stars would threaten neither: There's an Old ſaying, The Devil promiſes like a Merchant-man, but performs like a Man of War: 'Twas not ſo in the bleſſed year of 48, to my knowledge; I ſay no more — but — would I were at the Helm.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: So, Treaſon agen! you at the Helm! yes, of a Ship I would thou wert, to be thrown off, and plung'd to the bottom for a Mutinous Traytor.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Ha — what the loud Traytor to a man of my kidney? a Portly, Jolly, Fat man; a man of Faith and Belly: Away fool, 'tis your lean, your ſcraggy fellows that Plot miſchief; if the Pope himſelf had been a fat fellow, he had been honeſt.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Yes, as your Noble Anceſtors the Suſſex Whiggs were, or that Curſed Crew your Brethren of the Amſterdam-houſe, that cool their Coffee with the Breath of Rebellion, and hourly damn themſelves by Whiſpering Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come, Sirs, here's the Kings Health: Long live his Sacred Majeſty: kneel down, and caſt your Bonnet.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Not I Sir, you muſt ſpare me: I never kneel (not I) but to pray: beſides, I can drink no Healths, I am in a Milk-Dyet for the Scurvy.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: For the Pox I believe; Come Sir, it muſt be done, therefore uncover, and kneel.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Sir, we never uncover, 'tis not our method; we never uſe any Ceremony: with my Hat on — Let him live — But —

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Let him live — But — theſe are rare Raſcals.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A word more of Refuſal, and my Sword ſhall pare that body of thine into ſhape.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Well Sir, I ſubmit: But, Sir, tell not me: I underſtand my ſelf: Moles (though blind) can hear: let him live; but I wiſh for the Nations ſake — I wiſh my Council. —

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What! more muttering of Treaſon? your Council?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Well, I acquieſce: Drinks. I am ſilent: you will awake when the Sword's at your throats; you will I ſay, and repent this prophane drinking of Healths; and ſo farewell t'ee.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ha, ha; I knew there was no way to ſilence him but this: but ſee! Enter Townly and Millicent. here's Jack Townly coming with Sir Walter's Wife: Come, faith 'tis uncivil to hinder an Intrigue; prithee let's go.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Tis almoſt time now to viſit the Lady Lofty: I long to ſee you two rail a Courtſhip out.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'le be as good as my word, faith.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: The Captain's Lady ſay you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Millic.
sp.p: She Sir, the beautiful Livia.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: What! in love with me?

sp.speaker: Millic.
sp.p: I know not what you call in love; but, to my knowledge, ſhe was laviſh in her Commendations of you juſt now in the Garden; ſigh'd and look'd pale if your name were mention'd: and theſe are ſigns of ſomething extraordinary.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Kind Chance: She's the perſon I love more than Health: But I muſt ſift her further, this may be a trick. Aſide.
To Millicent. 'Tis a bleſſing, Madam, I am not ambitious of, ſince the charms of your Wit, Beauty, and Converſation, are to me all that can be extraordinary.

sp.speaker: Millic.
sp.p: Mine! Sir, you have but an ill ſtomach if you can ſubſiſt with the thin dyer I can afford you: I am of a Volatile temper, and only admit of this Gallantry of yours for the ſake of the mirth it brings with it: but the Captain's Lady has a paſſion for you, languiſhes, loves you; therefore if you would ſhare in my applauſe, go inſtantly, and Addreſs to her: A young Gallant ſhou'd (like a Tow'ring Falcon) fly at all games: I hate a dull, ſneaking, conſtant, tireſome fellow, that pins himſelf to one Ladies train, and will ſpend 14 long hours in praiſing the Dew on her under-lip, or the colour of her ſhooſtrings, whilſt ſhe is all the while curſing her company, and heartily wiſhes him hang'd.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: What a Devil does ſhe mean by this? S'death I was never ſo puzzl'd in my life. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Millic.
sp.p: In a word Sir; if you would purchaſe my good opinion, go and court this Lady: Come, I command you to do it: perhaps I have ſome reaſon for't.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Nay, you know, Madam, I want power to deny any Commands from you: Let me conſider a little.

sp.speaker: Millic.
sp.p: So, it begins to take, and by this means I ſhall get my Husband a Rival, too handſome, not to be belov'd as well as he. Whether Livia loves Townly, or no, I know not: Commend him ſhe did, and that may in time induce Love. — Well Sir, have you thought?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: I have, Madam, and for your ſake will Addreſs to her: I will ſtorm her ears with a peal of Rhetorick: accoſt her with a number of whining, amorous phraſes.

sp.speaker: Millic.
sp.p: And all lyes: Well Sir, ſhe's now at the Lady Lofty's: go, and get your Coach ready, and about half an hour hence I'le meet you there.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Of all Intrigues that ever I knew, this is the moſt quaint and pleaſant: Here o' one ſide is a fantaſtick husband, that courts me to court his wife: On the other ſide, his wife commands me to addreſs to another Lady, and (luckily) to the very perſon I love equal to my ſoul: Gad I think I'me a happy fellow: what ſhe deſigns by engaging me thus, I know not, but am reſolv'd to proceed for the ſweet ſake of variety. One, I am inform'd, loves me, and therefore muſt be courted; and the other is not inexorable, but may be courted.

lg.l: And where two Beauty's in compliance move,
The Devil's in that man that pines for Love.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Sir Walter, Gratiana and Livia.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: SIR, I am now ſo happy to tell ye your trouble is at an end; I am at home. —

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Wou'd my wits were at home too, that I might make a decent repartee — your Servant, Madam, 't no trouble.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip has a very, •… etty apartment here, Madam.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Small, but convenient, yet ſhall henceforth have a greater ſhare in my Eſteem, becauſe you like it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: A Plaguy ſharp-witted creature, this, Gad, I'me almoſt afraid to ſpeak to her, ſhe always runs one down ſo confoundedly.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip does me too much honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: For my part, I hate a Lodging next the ſtreet; the Coacheskeeps ſuch a perpetual Ratling, one had as good live in a Mill.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: I think theſe are private enough, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Private as Virgins thoughts, Madam. — Ah, this would be a rare place for my humour.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: What's that, Sir, to game in?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: No, to be Drunk in, Madam; that's my humour; 'tis the Talent of all the Wiſeacres; our family has been famous for't above this Five hundred years.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: I think you give a bottle, Sir, for the Creſt of your Coat.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: No, Madam, we give no Bottles, we drink off all the Bottles — we give the Cap of Fortune for our Creſt.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Otherwiſe called the Fools Cap. — Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Sir Jollynoſe Wiſeacre, my Great Grandfather, Madam, was the firſt man that bore it; and my Father Sir Toby Wiſeacre being a Favourite at Court, got it adorned with three Golden Bells in humour and imitation of the City-Cap of Maintenance.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: How I hate this Fop, that has nothing but dull Repartee, and vented in defiance of Wit and good Language. Madam, when the Gentleman's ſtory is ended, I ſhall expect you in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: What a whimſical creature is this — She's never two minutes in a humour.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: She's always uneaſie, Sir, in mens company.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: What, not love a man! Alas poor Animal, ſhe's miſerable enough, faith — Not love a man! why ſhe loſes the only bleſſing of her Creation.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Rather ſay ſhe reaps the only bleſſing, for Love in this age is as much ſophiſticated as Wine, and I think has as malignant effects.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Madam, the Wine I drink your Health in, is always unſophiſticated, and ſo is the Love I bear you; I am compounded, Madam, of nothing but Love and Wine; my heart is a meer Bunch of Grapes, from whence you may preſs the firſt running, luſcious Juice, together with the true ſpirit of affection unpall'd, or uncorrupted.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: There is nothing more corrupted than the love that Wine creates; therefore 'tis impoſſible you ſhould love well, that are ſo grand a profeſſor in drinking.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Oh the better for't, for you muſt know, Madam, I'me a ſneaking dog when I'me ſober — but I make Love like a Turk when I'me drunk.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Like a Turk indeed, for nothing but a Seraglio of women can then ſerve your turn; and if I am not miſtaken, your Lady has Jealouſie enough to reſent ſuch actions.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Nay, Gad, a Country-Copes, that has married a Player, cannot be more jealous; that's the truth on't: but I care not this for't; I laugh at it, faith, and that ſo mads her: beſides, I have now laid a ſnare for her: I ſet Jack Townly to court her, that ſhe may have the leſs leiſure to diſturb my paſſion for you: Did you praiſe him to her this afternoon, as I deſired you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Extremely Sir, and left 'um alone in her Cloſet; Ha, ſee yonder they come.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis ſo, I ſee the Rogue Townly follows my inſtructions: Well, adieu dear Madam, ſhe muſt not ſee us together; what, ſo familiar already — Gad my deſign goes on rarely.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Though the Love I had for this fool is vaniſht, yet I am reſolved to comply with him a little, if it be only to revenge my ſelf on his Wife for being jealous of me: here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Always thus retired, Madam, and melancholy; ſure this ſolitude muſt needs be prejudicial to your health; nay, and not only to your ſelf, but me, and all your friends, that loſe the pleaſure of your company: Come, I have ingag'd Mr. Townly here to wait on ye, handſome Mr. Townly: one I aſſure you, that is the moſt agreeable, moſt obliging, and beſt company of any man in Town.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Your Servant, Madam, I hope your Ladyſhip will prove this to her, for my part I am dumb.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: I know the Gentleman too well, Madam, to be ignorant of his perfections; I know he diſcourſes Elegantly, Dances finely; then his carriage is eaſie and courtly, beſides a moſt excellent quality he has in Singing.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: So, ſhe has found out a quality for me that I never knew in my felf, faith, that's Singing, for the Devil of any thing I can ſing but the Ballad of John Dory: and oh the wretched damn'd Sham-plot, &c.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Pray obſerve, Madam, what a delicate ſhape he has; what an attractive languiſhing; and then the prettieſt leg and foot — O Venus — but 'tis in vain for me to praiſe him. Apart to her.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: 'Tis as Sir Walter inferr'd, ſhe does love him; Aſide. and then, look Madam, he has the fineſt moulded face, the moſt taking features and graces; and each limb about his perſon ſo particularly graceful, that were I a woman of that brisk, free humour to entertain a Gallant — ſweet Mr. Townly ſhould be the man I would prefer before the world.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Her freeneſs in his Commendations declares her love to him: and thus far my deſigns has happy ſucceſs. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Though I was not ſo happy as to hear the laſt of your Diſcourſe, Ladies; yet, faith, I gueſs 'twas all in praiſe of me; for 'tis a vanity natural to us men, that when any one is commended by the Company, whatever whiſper ariſes afterwards, is imagined to be only a purſuance of the firſt applauſe, and therefore it is requiſite I make ſome return — Hum — hum —

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Come Sir, begin, then we'l ſtand ye fairly.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Firſt for you then, Madam, To Livia. your Eyes are the glittering Deities that command all hearts — And your Skin — ſmoother than Venus Doves, and white as Innocence — And you, Madam, To Millic. have a voice ſo raviſhing ſweet, that Angels peeping down to liſten to it, would think the Muſick of their ſpheres a diſcord, and then each feature has ſo much of Divinity in't: oh Heaven! And for your part, Madam, To Livia. nature out did her ſelf when ſhe fram'd you, your Face is the Epitome of Elizium, a delicate fore head, high, ſmooth, and white; a little ſtraight noſe, a breath Roſy and refreſhing; a pretty, ruddy, ſoft, round, dewy, melting under lip; and ſuch a hand, ſo white, ſo plump, ſo little, and the fingers ſo round, long, ſtraight, and ſmall — d's death, ſuch a ſight has power to make a man of fourſcore chatter, and frisk about the room like an over-grown Monkey.

sp.speaker: Mill. and Livia.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: For your ſake, Madam, to Mill. I could ſacrifice my own life, and for you, Madam, to Livia another mans; ſhould you be offended with me, to Mill. I ſhould hang my ſelf, or ſtab my ſelf, or poyſon, or drown my ſelf; and ſhould you, Madam, to Livia I ſhould hang, ſtab, poyſon, and drown my ſelf altogether.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: And ſhe muſt be a very unreaſonable perſon that expects more: but, Sir, in return of your Gallantry.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: No returns, I befeech you, Madam; nay, faith, take a little pity on me now, you ſee I am out of breath: beſides, to deal faithfully with ye, the weights of my Wits are all run down, and the Clock, by conſequence, muſt awhile ſtand ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: So, — now they are ingaged — I'le ſtrait away, and cunningly, by ſome means or other, inform my husband of her treachery to him, and love to this new Rival.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſign you ſpoke on an unpleaſing ſubject, you elſe doubtleſs could have held out longer.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Rather, Madam — the greatneſs of the Theme diſabled me only through a modeſt apprehenſion of my defect in expreſſions, when they ſhould be ſo divinely employed.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: What, is my Lady gone?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: I hope ſo, faith; ſhe's a very well-bred perſon, and I ſee underſtands manners: And now, Madam, behold at your feet a man that loves you more than his immortal part, his ſoul.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Nay, if Railery come to love once, the jeſt is gone.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: My Lady Millicent did me the honour to inform me of ſome expreſſions of yours in favour of me; each ſyllable of which is engraven in my heart; nay, the very thought of it has tranſported me ever ſince.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: My Lady Millicent inform him — What ſhould this mean? Commend him, 'tis true, I did, but 'twas more on her account than my own; and why ſhe ſhould let him know it, is to me a wonder.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Releaſe your Martyr from the Rack, dear Madam, and pronounce him happy.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Are you really then ſo miſerable a creature as to love me?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Love ye, Madam, I do moſt infinitely, but can never be miſerable, becauſe 'tis impoſſible you can ever be cruel.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: D'ee believe ſo?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Ay, and have all the reaſon in the world for't, faith; you can no more be unnaturally rigorous to a young Lover, than you can paſſionately dote upon an old Husband.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: A very fine, ſweet-natur'd opinion you have of me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Gad I think ſo.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: That to expel all unnatural cruelty, would oblige me to Cuckold my Husband by the way of Jeſt.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: No, faith, I meant by the way of Earneſt; I hate Jeſting mortally in ſuch caſes.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: And are not you a leud fellow for this — a damnable leud fellow? Come, ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Why, faith, I am ſo ſo — indifferent; we are all mortal, Madam, and ſubject to frailties; but I have this comfort, Gad, I ſin brave and nobly; and like a generous Robber, if I do venture damning, 'tis for a prize of value: Pox, I hate a ſneaking Crime, it gets a man no credit.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: An agreeable fellow this is; and if Millicent had known the real worth of the Jewel ſhe Ironically commended, I queſtion whether I ſhould have had the firſt refuſal.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: I wait your doom, Madam, in a cold ſweat, Mercy, I beſeech ye.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p:
If I ſhould take you into grace now, and prevent the approaching
Ague and Feaver, are you ſure you could be moſt paſſionately conſtant.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Stedfaſt as a Rock, Madam, fixt firm, not to be moved; I!

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: And will you ſay your Prayers every Morning and Evening, and thank Heaven for the timely bleſſing?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Ay, upon my Soul will I, with more zeal than ever I pray'd in my life.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Well, let me ſee you in the Park this evening, and then a Miſtreſs, or no Miſtreſs, a match, or no match; you ſhall know my mind, mum, — not a word — yours — bow and make your Exit: very well.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: So, I find I muſt bend my neck to the yoke, if I intend to plough in the Soyl, for ſhe means to uſe me as the Turkiſh Princeſſes do the Baſſa's; firſt make them their ſlaves, that they may afterwards be fit to be their husbands: but come what will, Love is my Captain, and I muſt forward now.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: What, Jack, art thou miſſing when there is ſuch excellent ſport yonder?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: What ſport, prithee?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Betwixt Wilding and my Lady Gratiana; he has ſo teiz'd her yonder in the Garden, and there has been ſuch bitter Jeſts between 'um, that now ſhe has quitted the place: Hark! I believe here they come; prithee obſerve 'um a little, I am now in purſuit of my little Welſh Miſtreſs, or I would keep thee company.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: The Scene muſt be pleaſant, for he rails as much againſt Women, as the greateſt Men: but I have no time to throw away at preſent.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Is there no place free from impertinence? I'me reſolv'd I'le change my Lodgings to morrow; I'le rather exclude my ſelf from all ſociety, than be thus tormented.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Modeſt ſenſe is ever thus ſlighted — 'tis the noiſie follies that are receiv'd, and take with your true women: Nay, there's ſo much indignity in ye, that ye are often deſtitute of common civility; and againſt all rules of breeding, ſhun a perſon that only makes ye an innocent viſit.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: A Fop, like a mad dog, ſhou'd ever be ſhun'd, there's danger and infection in his company.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A Fop! I ſee your Ladyſhips fancy quickens extremely; I beſeech you, how long have you and your ſex profeſs'd ſo much wit.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Ever ſince you and yours loſt it: what think you, Sir? does it not become me rarely?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Faith, no, 'tis not ſeen enough; you ſhould ſpot your face with it, inſtead of your patches, if you would have it diſcerned.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: I thank ye, and ſo I ſhould have you and your humourous brother Coxcombs continually buzzing about me to pick 'um off again.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: If we were upon any Treacherous deſign, I confeſs we might have occaſion; for a womans wit, like a Lawyers, is never conſiderable, but when abſolutely bent to do miſchief.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Then there's ſome applauſe due to us however: But I ſwear 'tis otherwiſe with you men, for you ever commit miſchief without wit.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: To our ſelves indeed, when we can be ſo weak to admire a piece of white point, a varniſht skin, and a corrupted heart; that indeed is miſchief without wit.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: And yet I have ſeen a perſon that has ſet up for a wit, wear his ſtockins out with kneeling, and kiſs the dirty Glove of a tawdry creature in the 18 penny Gallery, though the Owl had a charming wife of his own, whoſe fortune a week before purchas'd him a Barony.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis true, the Devil has power over us ſometimes; but if ever I loſe more blood in lo • ing of a woman, than I can get again with drinking a bottle, I'le give him leave to execute the worſt of his malice, and make me the firſt example.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: A dear bleſſing to women, for none ſure can be ſorry when a diſeaſe leaves her.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Pretty indifference! d's death, do not I know you cannot ſubſiſt without us? you would all dye like cramb'd chickens of the Pip, were it not for us men.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: You wou'd not only dye, but be damned, were it not for us women. Paſſionately.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, we ſhould be as free as Air, our boſoms calm, ſerene, and undiſturb'd, as Infants ſleep, or peaceful Innocence. — Ah, 'tis the life of Angels, the only happy eſtate; a woman, Gad, is the unneceſſary Parentheſis of Nature.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: And a man without that woman is a ſilly Cypher: Mark me, Sir, a Cypher! that perhaps, when a material figure is added, may make a conſiderable ſum; but alone is ſtill a cypher, and ſignifies juſt nothing.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: So, I have got much by railing — very much: If I could have been worded to death, I had, ere this, been paſt the help of Doctors. — How now! who have we here? what, my old Spunge of Rebellion! is he unſhakled ſtill?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, have I found you — you are one of thoſe that believe nothing — you fear no harm, not you; you are of the Tory-party, let the people be hang'd, you care not — the Nation is ſecure, you ſay: but, come Sir, I ſhall undeceive ye — oh impious Age, I ſhall convince you, Sir, I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Thy Ravens voice perhaps may bode ill fortune, but as yet I know none: Come, what's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Matter! rare matter — why, we are ridden, ſpur-gail'd, Jayl'd; the Turk, the French, the Moors, nay the very Devil will have us: Oh that ever the Noble family of the Whiggs ſhould live to ſee this day — we are beſet, the Enemy is coming — and yet we are aſleep: we are ſurrounded, and ſhall be confounded: ah (Gads woons) (forgive me for ſwearing) it was not ſo in Oliver's time.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, your villanous deſigns then kept you waking.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Theſe wicked times keep us more waking; the wiſe fraternity, together with my ſelf, as boldly, as pithy and politickly have now given our advice; but I fear in vain — no ſatisfaction, no return; no, though I have pen'd it my ſelf, and were I rightly rewarded, deſerve —

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: To be hang'd — for an audacious and impudent Libeller — what you, forſooth, are griev'd, and yet not for your ſelf, but for the Nation? why, how dareſt thou judg of Government? though of no more brain or birth than the Calf of the Shambles, yet you would be a States-man; and if each paſſage ſuit not with your judgment, the times go ill; all's loſt, you'l mutiny; a ſneaking, ſtigmatized, accurſed crew, drawn lean by vice, or like thee ſwoln and bloated.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: I bloated! what, becauſe — I am plump, plump, a man of kidney, or ſo — I bloated.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Villains, that can rail at Monarchs, and not bluſh, upbraid him by whoſe Clemency you live, that fearleſs lets you indulge your horrid Treaſons, nouriſh the muſty ſeeds of Old Rebellion, ſo ſure a guard is Sacred Royal Vertue; ye ſouleſs Inſects, ye rotten ſheep, that firſt your ſelves, and then infect a Nation.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Have you done yet? I think the Devil's in the fellow, he'l give no man leave to rail but himſelf: Sir, you talk largely, you do Sir; and let me tell you, though I am fat, I dare fight, Sir, — I can foyl as good a George-a-Green as your ſelf: but more of that as occaſion ſhall permit; and to let you ſee you do only chatter Magpye-like, without thinking, there's the Paper with all the Wiſe mens hands too't — Now read, and then judge; the wit and method I compos'd my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Wit — why thou double Traytor, dar'ſt thou aſſaſſinate that too — thou contrary to Wit as Loyalty.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Have I no wit? what! and have fin'd for Alderman; that's fine indeed — Come, read Sir, we ſhall have the note changed preſently.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A plague on your Wit and Method; here's not a line but tends to Villany.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall not be aſhamed to own it; there's no man there that will hide his face upon occaſion.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: To ſtir up Rebellion, and wound the boſom of his Country.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The beſt ſport, the beſt voyage ſure that ever man had.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh, here's the Captain now to be another ſpectator!

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: If he be a wiſe Captain, he will be of our ſide.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Mr. Wilding — Sir Barnaby, prithee old Boy tack about to Windward, and harken to me: Sailing a hunting this morning, we had not Cruzed above a League or two, but we found a Hare a-ground.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Tell not me of Hares, Sir, — if you had hunted a Biſhop out of the Nation, I ſhould have ſaid ſomething t'ee.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: 'Tis but manners though to hear him out, Sir, by your favour.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Hear him you may, but 'tis impoſſible to underſtand him; for he ſtuffs a ſtory ſo full of Sea-terms, the Devil himſelf can't tell what he means.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sir, may I never enter the Straits mouth agen, if it was not the beſt ſport that ever man ſaw: Oones he's for nothing, not he, but railing at Government, and cheating the People.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Right, nor will have any reward but hanging: Come, pray Sir, let me hear it, I love it; you have been a hunting, you ſay.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I Sir! and as I was ſaying we had not Cruzed above a League or two, but we found a Hare a-ground.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A Hare! ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Finding her thus, we preſently turned her a-drift; and then ſhe ſtood off, and the Dogs ſtood after, and we ſtood after the Dogs; Weſt Sou-Weſt, Tail and End.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Weſt, Sou-Weſt, the Sea-Calf thinks he's on Ship-board.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: After this, Sir, the Hare luff't, and the Dogs weatherd her agen; and then a ſtiff gale blowing, ſhe bore ſwiftly round us, and we went after large Top-ſails a trip, though one of our hearts of Gold making a ſhot at her, rak'd her fore and aft; then, Sir, ſpringing a Leak, ſhe bore down to the hedge; and there powdering in, we all boarded her: but, as the Devil would have it, my horſe running ſwiftly a-head, Gads bud, I tumbled over-board.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Did not I tell thee what a Tarpawlin-ſtory we ſhould have?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Tis better than your ſcrowl here, however, and has more ſenſe in't.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Senſe! why, does this Tun of mouldy Garbadg pretend to ſenſe? Harkee, Guts, dareſt thou drink a Gallon, the Kings Health; Load the great Cannon, or ungrapple a Fire-Ship? if not, thou'rt a Raſcal, and draw.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Well, Sir, when I have drunk a Gallon, I can draw.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Would I had thee a Ship-board to excuſe the boys penance, and be lickt for a freſh wind: what a ſtirs here with Religion! Come, if you are that godly perſon you ſay, ye are to follow me, and make one at a Bowl of Punch; I find Lime-Juyce and Brandy.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Not I Sir, I hate all Heathen Liquors.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Then if thou lov'ſt Chriſtian Claret, come ſup with me; I make a Collation to night, and invite my friends; and in plain terms, if you'l come, you ſhall be welcome.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: What, my Club I warrant: well, for their ſakes I may chance to viſit you; and ſo farewell.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'le go too, but upon another deſign: Sir, I'le wait on you.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: One pretty ſmile will recover all yet: come, I know this is but feign'd, thou art too well bred to be ill-natur'd.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p:
Upon my Souls — her is well enough preads to take cares and cautions of being cozen'd: look you, Shentlemens have creat deals of lyes and fraudulences
now a-days, and cheats poor Maids out of honour and virginities: pleſs us all.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: By Heaven he has not a grain of human nature in him that could wrong thee; believe me, and be grateful: by this dear hand I love ye like my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Like your Souls — Ay, that is fine falcity and equivocations: Look ye now, for you, Shentlemens, always loves your peddies petter than your own ſouls, a thouſand times.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: I would ſacrifice my body for a kind look from thee.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: I heard a Lords once ſay ſo much to a pegger-wench, I vow.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Imagine ſome Action that may be meritorious, and then lay your Commands upon me.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Her cannot commands, look you: Winny's hearts and poſoms is too ſoft and tender to uſe Exerciſes of Diſcipline: Will her make Poſitions and Oaths, that her can be moſt confoundedly conſtant. —

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Moſt zealouſly.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: And will her weep, and ſigh, and languiſh, and kneels at her feets one, three, four and twenty hours to wheedle her ſelf into her paſſionate affection and good craſes.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: I'le ſigh enough to raiſe a Storm at Sea, and weep another deluge.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: I pray you of all Loves then, weep now, for there is nothing in the creat 'orld that mollifies Winny's hearts and bowels, — ſo much as tears and weeping. — I pray you, Sir, begin: now weep, I beſeech you weep.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Now am I ſuch a dry Dog, I cannot ſqueeze a drop out to ſave my life — Pox on't, I have forgot my Onion too.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: In her own Country, that is, cood Montgomrey-ſhire; the Lovers will whine, and houl, look you, and make ferry ugly faces for whole days together: Come, let me ſee, do's her weep?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: I muſt do ſomething; I beſeech ye, Madam, do not make me too much unman my ſelf. Howling out.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul here is waters upon her cheeks: that's true, this is no diſſimulation; ferry good, ferry good: weep on, I pray you, till night, but be ſure come not from your knees, it will be preparations for Love and Paſſion: look you, and then her will viſit you again, and pleſs you with ſome brave conſolation and advices: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Conſolations and advices — 'death, this Jilt plays upon me; I find it now, but, Gad, I'le after her, and tell her my mind more plainly — for I ſee there's nothing to be done by fair means with any of that Country.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: THis is the ſtrangeſt adventure, Madam, that ever ſurpriz'd a Lover: Are you the charming perſon that Sir Walter adores?

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: He tells me ſo, Sir, and for whoſe ſake he has ingag'd you to addreſs to his wife.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Why, faith, I muſt needs ſay he has been very civil to me in that point: But I am ſo much a man of honour, I never deſert the perſon that has firſt ingaged me: I never change parties — not I.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Not if you have the odds of your ſide, I believe, Sir; and yet a Command from my Lady Millicent would make you venture hard.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: A ſmile from you would make me venture much more; I know not what influence ſhe may have upon me: but heaven keep you in a loving humour, or l'm afraid I ſhall never dye decently in my bed: Ten to one I ſhall ſwing to th' other World with a ſilken ſtring of your colours.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: And what a pitiful object will that be to the female ſpectator — to ſee ſo proper a man, and ſo conſtant a Lover, hang dangling like a Puppy out at a Garret-window.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Gad it will be a moſt diſmal, melancholy ſight, that's the truth on't: then for you to be attainted of Homicide — how can you hope to be ſav'd?

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: By pleading not guilty, Sir; for if the Devil and you fall out about the purchaſe — and you happen to be ſuſpended by the by — how do's this concern me? am I culpable? — But, come — to prevent effuſion of Chriſtian Lovers blood — for once I will be merciful.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Ah bleſſing, and ten thouſand Joys, and tranſports on thy heart for't — Gad it came very ſeaſonably, for I was juſt a falling into a ſwound for fear of a repulſe, I was ſeeking out for the Bottle of Mirabilis: but now all my diſorders vaniſh, and this heavenly Cordial retrieves my diſſipated ſpirits, and makes me all over Extaſie.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: My Wifes words have vext me, 'tis true, but ſhe ſpeaks nothing but the effects of Jealouſie.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Confuſion! — what ſhall I do now? a bottle of Mirabilis would be very neceſſary in this juncture, whatever 'twas in t'other.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p:
What's this I ſee? As I'm a true Son of Bacchus, here they are,
he kneeling and kiſſing her hand: here's fine work; I'm bob'd — down-right bob'd, fool'd, made a Chouſe — a double Cuckold, as Gad ſave me: Nay, nay, do not leave him, Madam, — the Son of a Whore, your Gallant, there — has more to ſay to ye yet: More, more, much more.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: I have a thought ſprung up however, and I hope 'twill proſper.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Sir, — Pray, with ſubmiſſion to ye, give me leave to ask ye a queſtion: Are not you a Raſcal, Sir? Ha —

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: A Raſcal, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Ay, a Raſcal, a Traytor, a Villain, any thing; nay, I ſhall come home to ye, if you provoke me.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Pray hold, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall not hold, Sir, — I am mad, and I will fight; you have wrong'd me — and abus'd your friend; and, now I think on't, I will beat you damnably: — And, now I think on't again, I will conſider firſt — Ah, moſt abominable Varlet what, two at once: Come, come, prepare.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Prepare! for what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: To be kill'd, Sir, only to be diſſected, anatomized like a Chicheſter Cock-Lobſter, or ſo; that's all. —

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: All in the Devils name: — But pray, Sir, do but hear me ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: No, Sir, not till I've •… t your throat, Sir; 'tis not my way; when I have done that, you may have the priviledge to ſpeak what you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Nay if you are ſo reſolute, I muſt not dye defenceleſs: Come, — come on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Come on, Sir, come you on, Sir; — what a Pox, ſure I underſtand what I have to do: — But hark you Jack, to argue coolly now upon this matter: Come, put up; Was I ſo obliging to cauſe an intimacy betwixt thee and the wife of my own boſome? and would'ſt thou affront me and her ſo much, nay be ſo ungrateful — ſo falſe, ſo treacherous, to deſert her, and ſeek to corrupt my Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Your Miſtreſs!

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, my Miſtreſs, the Idol of my ſoul, the Cordial of my heart, the Light of my eyes: My Miſtreſs! what a Pox, do you queſtion that? Come, draw, Sir, draw.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you ſee I dare draw; but aſſure your ſelf, I was ignorant of your being concerned here; and my buſineſs with her, was only an humble ſuit, that ſhe would do me what good offices ſhe could in commending me to your Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: And was that all, faith? What a Dog am I now to abuſe ſo honeſt a fellow. Come, put up agen: But was that all, faith, ſwear, bounce out a ſwinger by way of confirmation.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: By the God of Love, and the more Celeſtial Beauty of that Divine Creature, your Wife — I ſwear. — Pray Heaven this lye don't choak me. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Why, look now — what a Dog am I — Deed Jack I beg thy pardon: I am ſomewhat haſty. — But I only make an offer, or ſo; — I would not have fought with thee for all my jeſting.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: I do believe thee, I • aith, Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Either my ears deceiv'd me, or I heard my husbands voice — Ha, 'tis ſo, yonder he is, and Townly familiarly talking with him; nay, then I ſee my Plot has taken little effect — I'le ſtand aſide and liſten.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: To morrow, Jack, I'm oblig'd to wait on my Miſtreſs, therefore be very careful in addreſſing to my Wife.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Well, Sir, ſince you will have it ſo. —

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: His Miſtreſs — rare Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: I'le vow the Domeſtick Animal at home is grown ſo jealous of late, there's no enduring her.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: 'Tis pity, Sir, ſhe has that fault; ſhe's very handſome.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: I, were ſhe but another mans wife, ſhe were a bleſſing; but the Devil's in't, ſhe's mine: Jack, ſhe's mine; I'm fed up with an everlaſting diſh of Mutton; yeſterday ſhe was Mutton, to day ſhe's Mutton, and to morrow ſhe will be Mutton; and for a man to feed eternally upon Mutton, — a Pox on't, 'tis unreaſonable.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Sir, though ſhe be Mutton to you, ſhe's Veniſon to another man; every look from her is a delicious banquet; and a man muſt, as you ſay, be her husband to be cloyed with it.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
