sp.p: Come, we ſhall find her at the Maſquerades to night; then, dear Rogue, do but wheedle her finely, and thou wilt oblige me for ever.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: If I fail, let me be an Eunuch; ſo I think I'm a lucky fellow.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Is it for this then I have been ſo conſtant? for this have ſlighted ſtill the young and brave, and like Penelope, kept my tempted vertue, maugre the vice of this deluding age: nay, does my beauty deſerve only this? My May of blood would give my cheeks a bluſh, greater than would appear on proof of Infamy, did he but know I had an Imperfection. And am I ſlighted thus? thus left — ſold to another, and by my husband too — whom I have lov'd — far, far beyond his merit. Teach me then, ye Powers, Revenge, and Jealouſie inſtruct an injur'd woman: 'Tis done — Townly ſhall be the man; I'le inſtantly write to him, and let looſe all my Charms to retrieve him from Livia. Then ſhall my husband find too late, that Marriage ſhould have a reliſh of Love, as well as Duty.

lg.l: For may I prove the fool that he deſign'd,
If I make not him the greateſt of mankind.

sp.speaker: Townly.

lg.l: HAppy the man, moſt happy muſt he prove,
That lives like me, crown'd with ſucceſs in love.
A thouſand bleſſings wait on his Deſires;
Bliſs glads his heart, and kind Occaſion courts him.
Beauty, the Goddeſs of the Univerſe,
Unarms her killing eyes, and meets him equal.
Whilſt fierce Delights, and Joys profuſely given,
Shoot through, and almoſt cloy his Soul with Heav'n.

sp.p: Was ever Luxury in love like mine? What! two at once? and two ſuch Beauties as Livia and Millicent? By heav'n 'tis too much, and I grow jealous of my happineſs; and yet my Aſſignation with the firſt, and this Letter from the laſt, confirms the certainty. Well, if this be not a falſe ſcrowl — my honeſt friend Sir Walter muſt excuſe me in a certain punctilio about his Wife; I ſhall never be able to keep Covenants; Gad I muſt beg his pardon.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Whoſe pardon is this you are ſo zealous to beg, Sir? and what Covenants are theſe that are ſo difficult for you to keep?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Thoſe betwixt my heart and you, Madam; and therefore of whom ſhould I beg pardon but you? for though you have charm'd me with the proſpect of tranſporting hopes, yet ſo frail is humane nature; and I, amongſt the reſt, ſo faulty, that my ſoul hovers in the Purgatory of doubt, not knowing what I deſerve, nor whither I am to go.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: A great proof of your deſert, Sir, may be made by your ſervice; and we, women, like Merchants, gueſs a ſervant's Merit by his fidelity — let me ſee! Have you been careful in the firſt point, and kept my Letter ſafe?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Safe! Judg you elſe: 'twas here quilted in my Coat, next my heart, and done up with as much care as a Miſer does his broad Gold, when he's afraid of robbing.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: And deſign'd to be ſent as a Trophy to your new Miſtreſs Livia.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: My new Miſtreſs!
Jealouſie — good — Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I vow I heard you were under the Surgeons hands for a ſtrange bruiſe in your knee, occaſion'd by your inceſſant kneeling to her.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Gad I was afraid ſhe had heard I had been there for ſomething elſe. Aſide.

I kneel to her! why, Madam, I ne're had ſuch a thought; I ne're made ſuch a motion, ne're bow'd, hardly ever pull'd off my hat; and if I ſpoke any flaſhy, unballanc'd words to her, 'twas only in obedience to your Commands: my heart ador'd you, though my tongue flatter'd her.
So, now I'm going to be an excellent Raſcal. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I did expect you could ſing to this tune: you can outflatter a Town-Poet, and out-lye a Mercer of Pater-noſter-Row. Thus clouding Deceit under a pretty, modiſh, methodical way of Gallantry, you prove equally treacherous both to her and me: What ſay you? would you not prove ſuch a villanous ſort of a creature?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: 's death I'd be a Dog firſt: Treacherous! no, Madam, 'tis to your Altar I ſacrifice: to you, and only you my heart pays tribute: Livia's a thing remote, when you are by; unknown, a very ſtranger; I hardly ever ſpoke to her, but when I was half aſleep.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Now have I a great mind to be credulous, but that lying face of yours does ſo ſtartle my Reſolutions: but come, for once I'le put you to the Teſt, and give you leave to viſit me; then, if you prove a Jewel —

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: You will wear me: Nay, nay, that muſt of neceſſity follow.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: My Lady Millicent! Don't you intend to Dance? they are all ready to begin.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Ha! Livia! — I was juſt coming to wait on you, Madam, He's confus'd: now I ſhall note their carriage. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: If ſhe have over-heard any thing now, I'm in a fine condition. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Mr. Benedick has bin giving me a Song yonder: Mr. Townly, pray come hither and ſing it, you have a good voice.
Ingrateful man! Is this your conſtancy? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: So, there's one ſhot already; I ſhall be pepper'd. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: We ſhall ſup late to night, 'tis paſt ſev'n o' Clock.
Mr. Townly, you have skill in Watches, pray give me your Judgment in this.
You can't hold out I ſee. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: The Devil take me if I know how I ſhould at this rate. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Nay Mr. Townly, pray come hither: a good Singer is ſo hard always to be intreated.
You are very ready to obey her. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Not I faith, Madam; I deſign'd only to be civil.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Mr. Townly, pray help me to ſet the Hand right here, I ſhall ſpoil my Clock for want of skill.
sp.stage: Struggles to go, and Livia holds him.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Come, Sir, Begin, begin.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: What! are you deaf o'th' ſuddain?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: 's death what ſhall I do? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Pray make no delays, Sir, but come hither.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Pray make no delays Sir, but ſing.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Madam, I beg your pardon, he has ſome skill at this.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Madam, I beg your pardon, he has more skill at this.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: s'death I ſhall be quarter'd. Aſide.
Why then, by heav'n, I have skill at neither. I am plagu'd with an eternal Cold, and the moſt ignorant Artificer in the world beſide: Hark, the Muſick begins, we ſhall be too late. —
Anon we ſhall have more leiſure. To Livia.
At night we ſhall meet alone. To Mill.
Come, come, to the Muſick, to the Muſick.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Diſcovers the Captain, Wilding, Sir Walter, Benedick, Townly, Gratiana, Millicent, Livia, Winifrid, ſeated.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: COme, let's have t'other Dance, the Ladies are not warm yet.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come, now let's talk of Shipping: Dean has built a brave Frigot, they ſay.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Prithee Tarr ſhew none of thy Sea-breeding now: Dancing is a gentile quality, which you Sea-ſharks underſtand not: Come, ſhall thou and I go and drink a quart of Brandy to warm our ſtomachs.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: More drink ſtill! why thou art grown a meer ſpunge, do'ſt nothing but ſuck in, and ſqueeze out all day long: but I muſt confeſs 'tis natural to you all; and a man may as well know a fooliſh Country-Knight by his down-right drinking, as a Yeoman of the Guard by his infallible eating.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: What! another Sea-joke? Ha, ha, well ſaid Tarr. —

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Do you not wonder, Madam, that having been ſo baffled at our 〈◊〉 laſt meeting by your Wit and Diſdain, that I have the confidence to appear agen?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Not at all for your true Spaniel; the worſe he is us'd, grows ſtill the civiller.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, now another Leſſon, the Ladies are impatient.
sp.stage: The Gentlemen ſit down as to play.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Oh! 'uds ſo, here comes my Uncle, now we ſhall have a full Conſort.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sir Barnaby, welcome, come pray let's have ſome of your skill.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Prithee obſerve with what ſtate he takes place.
sp.stage: Sir Barnaby ſeats himſelf at the upper end.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Caeſar in triumph look'd not half ſo big.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: No, nor thought himſelf ſo worthy: hark you Sir Walter, a word with you; prithee deal ingenuouſly, Does your Uncle play well on this Inſtrument?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Oh to a miracle, Sir, and has the beſt grace you ever ſaw.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Say you ſo?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: His touches are always ſo ſoft and gentle: beſides, I have obſerv'd (Gentlemen) that your thick ſquab-hand and ſhort thumb-like fingers always become a Lute extremely.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, that indeed I ne'r took notice of.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Strike F-fa-ut ſharp, and ſing the Song.

lg.l: FArewell my Lov'd Science, my former delight,
Moliere is quite rifled, then how ſhould I write?
My fancy's grown ſleepy, my quibling is done;
And deſign or invention, alas! I have none.
But ſtill let the Town never doubt my condition;
Though I fall a damn'd Poet, I'le mount a Muſician.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: I got Fame by filching from Poems and Plays,
But my Fidling and Drinking has loſt me the Bays;
Like a Fury I rail'd, like a Satyr I writ,
Therſites my Humour, and Fleckno my Wit.
But to make ſome amends for my ſnarling and laſhing,
I divert all the Town with my Thrumming and Thraſhing.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I have a trick to get him away inſtantly.
What is't you ſay, friend? an Army raiſing, and 20000 in Arms already?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: That there are, I ſaw 'em muſter'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: For the deſtruction of the Saints! this is but cold news.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: They will not leave a Rebel in the Land.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Nay you muſt march, Uncle; you muſt ſwing; I do not doubt but I ſhall ſee you exalted for the honour of our family.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Unnatural Rogue! do'ſt hope to ſee me hang'd? Hang'd! — Gad that word has a plaguy ſound: but come, let the worſt happen, I can but turn; the Saints may revoke, if the game be near loſing: Come, come, I can turn, I can turn.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I knew that news was worſe than an Ague to him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A Pox on't, the Women are all gone too, and I have had ne'r a buſs of my Welſh Miſtreſs; I muſt go ſeek her.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: D'ee hear that, friend?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Let him go; the old Hound hunts upon a falſe ſcent, for I have her in chace my ſelf.

div.stage: Sir Walter goes to the Door, and returns.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Jack, Jack, my Wife's gone away alone man: Go, go for ſhame: — nay, prithee dear Jack, go now.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Well Sir, I follow her, ſince you'l have it ſo. But the Stars point otherwiſe to night; I am elſewhere engag'd, I thank my fortune. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Now if that Fairy have but Welſh Devils enough to charm the Captain for one hour, I ſhall love Mountgomery the better as long as I live for't.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Prithee no more excuſes, but conſent to go with me to morrow.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Haſt thou the conſcience to deſire me to be ſtung agen by that Waſp, that Viper of Women, Gratiana?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: I have, nay and thou ſhalt not deny me neither.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt; I had rather Duel three hours, than Ward her words three minutes: her Tongue is like the Pendulum of a Clock, and ſhe wants nothing but talking in her ſleep to make it a perpetual motion.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: And yet for all that thou lov'ſt her, if the truth were ſifted throughly.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Love her! yes, as I do bad Wine, or an unſound Wench.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Come, I know thy humour, and can make this Poſition; Thou never railed'ſt heartily at any Woman, thou did'ſt not then, or afterwards fall in love with.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Perhaps her Charms do not equal others.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Nay ſhe's beautiful every way: however, do an honourable courteſie, and go to aſſiſt thy friend, for my little Winifrid is to be with her.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p:
Pox on thee, thou art ever ingaging me in ſuch affairs: I confeſs I have an inclination to ſee this Woman agen; and if I prove his words true, and fall in love with her, how this unmerciful Rogue will laugh at me: I am untainted
yet, and am ſure can hold out one skirmiſh more, whatever happens after.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Well, haſt thou thought, ſhall I truſt thee?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You will have your humour, Sir, and I'm oblig'd to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Here let's part then, and to morrow I'le call upon you at your Lodging.
I think I heard her voice juſt now here abouts, perhaps this old Kite has ſnatch'd her up before me: Gad I muſt go and ſee.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: 'Tis as he ſaid; there is an Army raiſing, a great one too, and the fraternity will be ſwing'd, I profeſs: Well, ſtay then Brother Barnaby, what will you do, Brother, to ſave your neck? why look you, Brother, you muſt Conform; and as you have ſwore up your own party, now you muſt ſwear 'em down: 'Tis true, Brother, you are a Raſcal; but ſo are many more that are preferr'd, therefore you muſt now ſpeak for the King: Diſguiſe your ſelf; get a Commiſſion, and fight for the King: Impeach your quondam Brethren that were againſt the King, and ſo, dear friend and brother, you may ſave your ſelf — by the King.

div.head: SCENE III.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: I Have miſtook, and follow'd a wrong Woman, and now cannot find the way out agen: Hark! ſome-body is coming; perhaps 'tis the Captain, what ſhall I do? Oh, here's a door open, I'le go in and hide my ſelf till they are paſt by.

div.stage: Enter Townly, and Livia after him.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Where are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Here divine Creature, waiting for the bleſſing with more Zeal, than Pilgrims a reward for their Devotion: Where (where) 's your Husband Sweet? your husband! your property I mean, that ruſty Animal; abroad, or aſleep, or drunk, or where?

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Speak lower, Sir; he's not ſo far off, but Jealouſie can quickly ſpur him hither: Go, get you in here, I muſt be your Jaylor, and lock you up for a-while, till I ſee how my Husband is employ'd: Come, haſte, haſte, the door is open already.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: If every man for ſo delicious a ſin had no ſeverer a penance, the World would grow monſtrous wicked in a ſhort time.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: If my Cauſe were to be tryed in a Court of Equity, I queſtion whether the moſt Reverend Head could blame my proceedings: in my opinion the ſcales are equal; for if my Husband ſlights me, to ſeek a Miſtreſs that ſlights him; 'tis but reaſon that I ſhould ſlight him, to love a man that adores me: but then Honour and Religion ſtart up, two Bug-bears, and fright me terribly: but then agen, I love Townly more terribly: Honour is a fine thing, but Townly is a finer thing: What ſhall I do? Well, I'le firſt go and ſee whetehr my husband be ſafe, and then reconcile my ſelf to Honour and Religion as well as I can.

div.stage: Enter Sir Walter with a Light.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Townly is, I hope, by this time at home ſolacing my Spouſe: ſo ſhe is ſafe, Gad that's a very honeſt fellow, as good a ſoul as breathes; and the very life of my deſign, becauſe 'tis a harmleſs Rat, a baſhful, unfleſh'd young fool: why, I might ha' bin a Cuckold, had another man undertook the buſineſs but he; were ſhe as looſe as Lais, he'd not underſtand her: This 'tis to have Judgment to diſtinguiſh men now: — Well, he I ſay is with my Spouſe, the Captain is gone out after his Welſh Miſtreſs, and I am coming in here to his Wife; ſhe muſt be there in her Cloſet, for I'me ſure I ſaw her come up Stairs.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: What! come already, my life, my ſoul?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: What's here a man? ha! Townly! the Devil! 'tis impoſſible. Oh Raſcal! Oh Traytor! what and conceal'd in the Cloſet too! Townly runs back and ſhuts the door. Impudently lying here perdue, for my Miſtreſs, like a Villain, when he ſhould be at home courting my Wife like an honeſt fellow: Oh the Devil! this is a treachery inſupportable; and d'ee hear, Sir, I ſhall ſtorm your Caſtle; I ſhall demoliſh; I ſhall ſlit that dog's noſe of yours, incorrigible Raſcal!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: within. — So, ho, — where ſits the Wind? what noiſe? what ſtorm is this?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Ha! the Captain return'd? already too? had that Welſh Gipſy no more ſenſe than to leave her Cully ſo ſoon? A Pox o' their Mungril Welſh courtſhip, they make love like Sparrows; the Intrigue is no ſooner begun, but ended.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: My Husband return'd — Oh, I'me undone.

div.stage: Enter the Captain, and Livia peeping.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How now! who's there? — ha! — a Sword drawn? where are my Servants? Lock up all the doors there, here's a Jeſuit, a Thief, a Fox in my Bed-Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Hold, hold! 'tis I, Captain, 'tis I, Watt, Watt, honeſt Watt, do'ſt not know me? why 'tis I man, thy friend Watt, I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Friend Watt, with a Pox! what does my friend Watt do in my Chamber o' this time of night, hoh?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p:
I come to bring thee news, old Culverin; thy well-rigg'd Frigot
is grappl'd, her Sails unfurl'd, her Gun room blown up, and all her treaſure in the Hold rifled and plunder'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: My Frigat! why then I ſay, my friend Watt, with a Pox to him, is a damn'd lying Raſcal; for my Lieutenant came from Sheerneſs this morning, and told me ſhe was as tite as ever, and ready to ſet Sail.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Sheerneſs! ha, ha; well ſaid apprehenſion: here's the wit of a Tarpawlin now; one ruffling Storm frights away all their brains, to make room for the fumes that make them Valiant; but know, friend, that I mean a Frigat of another nature; thy Wife, thy Wife man!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: My Wife! why what of her?

sp.speaker: Sir Wal.
sp.p: Nay, no great matter, only ſhe is beſet, made unlawful prize, and to night to be grappl'd and boarded, that's all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: All in the Devils name! a very pretty All, faith: but hark you Sir Watt, or Coxcomb, or what may a man call you? if you run your Lancaſhire-Jeſts on me, I ſhall ſwinge you; I ſhall thraſh you, in plain terms. D'ee ſee, Sir, therefore be ſerious: — My Wife d'ee ſay?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Nay if you are ſo Cholerick for nothing, I care not this for't; be a Cuckold, grow ridiculous; deſpair, and then hang your ſelf on the top of the Main-Maſt: Gad I'le not value it the cutting a corn, ſince you are ſo uncivil.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'Sbud ſpeak to the purpoſe, or by Boreas I will eat thee up, as I would do a Sea-bisket.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: What a damn'd Canibal-Rogue is this? Gad he looks as if he would eat me indeed — why then I ſay agen, thy Wife, thy Helen, thy Octavia, was this night to be engaged in an Intrigue; the buſineſs and place is only ſuppos'd, but the voracious Pirate is by my induſtry ſurpriz'd, detain'd a Priſoner of War, and confin'd to that Cloſet there.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How! a Raſcal ſurpriz'd in my Wives Cloſet? So, ho: bring out the Mortar-piece there: 'Oones I'le ſurprize him with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Hold, hold, here comes your Lady; — urge her to a Diſcovery; command the key, and obſerve her excuſes: So, ſo, I think I ſhall be reveng'd now.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: If this project fail, I'me undone.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Your Servant, Madam; pray if a man may ask a civil queſtion, What news from the Straits? it ſeems (good Pinnace) you were to be Boarded to night — hah!

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Boarded, Sir?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Grappl'd, clapt a-ſtern; nay, and in danger to prove a Fire-ſhip — forc'd to a ſurrender by a through-ſhot betwixt Wind and Water, and then to be Mann'd by the Enemy in the Fore-Caſtle and Poop — with a Pox t'ee.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: I wiſh you would give your meaning, Sir, in plainer terms, for I am utterly unprovided of an anſwer to this.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Ay, alas poor Innocence, ſhe knows not what you mean, not ſhe.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, no: Come give me the key of this Cloſet, I'le ſhew my meaning preſently; What, d'ee tremble? Come, the key, the key, where is't?

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: What key, Sir?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What key, Sir! the key that unlocks the Bawdy door to your Stallion, that lies there in the Bilbo's: I'le feez him: 'Sbud I'le have him condemn'd by a Jury of Tarpawlins; firſt flea'd, then hung by the heels at the Yard-arm, a dreadful example to all ſuch Cuckoldmakers: — the key I ſay, the key.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Now, dear fortune, be propitious. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come where is't? by Mars, my Lady Strumpet, I ſhall give you a ſalt Eel; I ſhall ſhow you a touch of my Sea-office if you trifle any longer.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: But why thus angry, Sir? you ſhall have the key, and inſtantly; but ſhew ſo much humanity to your poor Wife, one that has lov'd you (Heav'n knows too tenderly), to let her ſpeak: give her time to unfold this myſtical matter; let her plead her Innocence before ſhe be condemn'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Innocence! ay, a Whore has a wonderful ſtock of Innocence indeed: you are devout, are you? this is your zeal, is it? 'Sbud I ever thought there would come no good of your Devotion, you were ſo early at it.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Is my Integrity ſuppos'd my Crime then? muſt that be my Accuſer? my Husband ſhould have kinder thoughts; and you, my friend, are too much a Gentleman ſo to condemn me; Heav'n knows how little I deſerve this Ignominy.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ay, ay, weep: this rain ſhall not lay the duſt, the Stallion muſt be produc'd; he muſt Spouſe, he muſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: I am her Friend now, but I was her Fool and Coxcomb an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Produc'd, Sir: Can you think I would conceal him? Can you believe your Wife, the partner of your Bed, and deareſt thoughts, could know a ſecret that concerns your Honour, and keep you ignorant? See here the whole diſcovery; my heart was too full of grief to let me ſpeak the fatal ſtory, and therefore I committed it to Writing.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Your heart too full! your crime was too foul rather: but come, let's ſee; here's a pretty modeſt ſcrowl, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: The Devil's in theſe Women; they had rather do that buſineſs, than talk of it any time.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p:
Here, here's the key; now do it cunningly, and gain my love for ever. To Silvia.
Aſide.

p.q: If Love were to be judg'd by Jealouſie, then Jealouſie were to be excus'd by Love; but the reaſon of the one, and the unreaſonableneſs of the other, makes paſſionate Love ſuſpected, and Jealouſie hated; though to be jealous, is really to love, as to love is to be jealous, argued largely in the Amour of Min Heer Van Belgor, Admiral to the States-General; and the Skinckimurra Brachia del Pegoe, Wife of Preſter-John.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What the Devil is all this? Oones I can't underſtand a word on't: Do you?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Hum! Skinckimurra Pegee, hum! ay, 'tis as you ſaid, Captain, a very pretty modeſt ſcrowl: Come, let's ſee further.

sp.speaker: Read.
sp.p: Courteſie is only a pretence, and Friendſhip grown a deceit, for your friend, Sir Walter, has bin theſe ſix months ſolliciting me unlawfully — Livia makes ſigns to Silvia to open the door. Ha! ſay you ſo — I underſtand that, Sir, — hum!

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: That, Sir! pray let's ſee't. This damn'd Jilt will diſcover all. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'Sbud this is a very fine buſineſs, pray read on, Sir.

p.q: Your friend, Sir Walter, has bin theſe ſix months ſolliciting me unlawfully.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Friend! ay, a ſweet friend, fine damn'd friend — hum.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt. reads.
sp.p: And you are conſcious to your ſelf that you were formerly very familiar with his Wife — Hah, hum — who muſt underſtand that? there's a bus'neſs — hum — who muſt underſtand that, I ſay? Familiar with her; not ſollicit, but familiar, intimate, profoundly acquainted — familiar with her: you have no Off-ſpring, no Iſſue, no Sons of Whores begotten on her body, have you, Sir? Hah, hum.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I! prithee leave thy prating: why, I hardly know her: I never came within ſhot of her in my life; theſe are Tricks, Wheadles, Clokes to cover the main matter, pray, Miſtreſs, come to the point, the Raſcal in the Cloſet there, the bawdy Intrigue — Where's that? where's that?

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Be careful now, or we are loſt. Aſide to Silvia.
Here, here, Sir, pray obſerve it, fix your eye here ſtedfaſtly.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, what's here?

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: And you, Sir Walter.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: I warrant you, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Livia. reads.
sp.p: The deſign being woven thus between you, about one anothers Wives, Townly makes a forcibly Entry upon the Premiſſes, by order of my Lady Millicent, who, in a kind of a diſorderly manner, orders Mr. Townly and I to ſtate a queſtion in the Mathematicks, with deſign to put us all into diſorder; but Sir Walter politickly ſifting into the matter, and well knowing that Townly, and my Lady Millicent, had inſtructed Sir Barnaby to wheadle the Caprain into a belief, that Welſh Winifrid and Benedick were playing at Hot-Cockles in the Mulberry-Garden, confirm'd the matter to be carried on by Wilding and Gratiana, who were to be expos'd, and Townly confin'd to the Cloſet upon due conſideration: D'ee underſtand me? Whilſt ſhe is bantring them with this Letter, Silvia opens the door, and lets out Benedick inſtead of Townly. So, ſhe has done it.
sp.stage: She holds her hand behind her, and Silvia gives her the key agen.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'Sbud, the Devil, though he were a Scrivener, could not underſtand this: Do you, Sir Walter?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Not a ſyllable, not I, as I am a true Knight.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Oh confounded misfortune! ſome damn'd Raſcal, that had hid himſelf here, has made his eſcape inſtead of me. Peeping out of a window.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Pox on't, this is another whim; 'tis plain now, there's not one word of ſenſe in the whole Letter; thou Spawn of a Syren, give me the key without more Demurs, or by the North Star I will ſo mawl thee. —

sp.speaker: Livi •… .
sp.p: Why then there 'tis: you can ſtoop and take it up to make your diſcovery, I hope.
sp.stage: Flings the Key on the ground.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How! my Lady Impudence! are you in earneſt? Aloud.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, earneſt; why thou baſe, ingrateful, jealous-headed, ruſty, ſnoring, fumbling creature, thou worn out ſtump, thou very husband: — had the Devil ſo much power over thee, to make thee ſuſpect my honeſty? What! a perſon of my Candor, Religion and Virtue; a perſon of my birth and education; a perſon of my modeſty and wife-like patience; and for the Aſſertion of that uſeleſs Tool there, that Knight of the Burning Peſtle, that Lancaſhire-ſpoke for a Spinning-wheel, that fool of Quality, thing of title, and nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: So, ſo: ſhe's in her Altitudes now, but we ſhall fetch her down preſently, Captain.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Had it been from a witty man, 'twere to be excus'd; but from him is a ſin of Ignorance, not to be pardoned.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Good! very good: Come, Sir, the Cloſet, the Cloſet, the Gentleman wants company.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'Tis a merry Gale now, but here's a Storm coming.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! we are all undone, by a ſtrange miſtake; inſtead of Mr. Townly, I let Mr. Benedick out of the Cloſet, who it ſeems had hid himſelf there.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Ha! what is Townly there ſtill then?

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Too true I fear.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: The Devil has a mind to expoſe me, and I ſtrive againſt it in vain: Curſt, helliſh, ſpiteful chance, 'tis impoſſible now to retrieve it, I have ſo rail'd at them.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Plant your ſelf there, Sir Walter, in a poſture of Defence, whilſt I tack to Windward, and give the firſt Broadſide.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Stay, Sir, ſtay a minute, as you would have me live, come back a little: Kneeling. Ah, can you then be ſo cruel to ſhame me for ever? what though I have bin indiſcreet, and ſpoke too much, will you expoſe your poor Wife for her firſt fault? Conſider how I have lov'd you, with what a tender kindneſs I have nurs'd you, kiſs'd you, hugg'd you, cheriſh'd you, comb'd your head, air'd your ſhirt, and lac'd your night-cap, claſp'd you in my arms, and let you ſnore with patience; and though you were then a heavy lump, a Statue, I've made you, ſtir, and move, and live a little.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Oh! ſits the Wind there already? no Mermaid, Syren; I'le ſtop my ears to all but Revenge, thou Bankſide Mawdlin, Diſeaſe of Matrimony, unworthy the honour of being my Wife, and only fit for the Boatſwain, or Swabber.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Can nothing mollifie your heart? Sir Walter, be you merciful then, 'tis in your power to ſave all yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt,
sp.p: In mine! what a Ninny, a Lancaſhire-tool, a Spoke for a Spinning-wheel? hum — in my power ſay you?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sir Walter guard the door; and if he ſtrives to eſcape, kill him. Houſewife, come you and hold the Candle. To Silvia: they enter the Cloſet.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: There's no way but to leap over the Balcony — and I muſt venture.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: What thinks your Ladyſhip of an Intrigue now — a Love-combat, a Jugling trick? Hey, paſs, come aloft here; what! I am a fool, am I? Townly is the man, the taking-man, and I am a thing, a thing of nothing; but you ſhall find now, that he ſhall be nothing, nor (y' Gad) have nothing before I part with him. How now! who comes here? Give the word.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: 'Tis I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: I Sir! 'tis well you ſpoke, Gad I would have whipp'd you through the guts elſe.

sp.speaker: Silv.
sp.p: Look up, Madam, and ſmile, there's no body in the Cloſet; Mr. Townly is gone, and as I believe, made his eſcape over the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Then Fate's my own agen, beyond danger of Relapſe, and I will uſe it moſt triumphantly.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Oones here's no body.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: What, what! no body? that's a good Jeſt indeed, Ha, ha, no body?

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Your ſervant ſweet Sir, Curt'ſies to him. with all the ſubmiſſion and reſpect due from an obliging Wife to a ſcurvy, jealous — no Husband: let me deſire to know how Mr. Townly does, and how you have dealt with Mr. Townly, and how Mr. Townly has dealt with you: — Heaven avert my doubt, I fear you have murther'd him, Ha, ha, ha.
sp.stage: Feigns to weep, and then burſts out a laughing.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'Sbud I'le mawl this fooliſh Knight, I'le teach him to play tricks with me.

div.stage: Enter Sir Walter in a ſneaking, ridiculous poſture.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Well, what now?

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Your ſervant ſweet Sir; Curt'ſies to him too. the laſt courteſie you did me, in concealing my Intrigue was ſo generouſly perform'd, that I vow there is no favour you would demand, that I think I could deny: Curt'ſies to him too. Pray, Sir, ſpeak, I beſeech you let me be grateful.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Well, Madam, though the Devil is your friend, and ſo forth, yet I have eyes, Madam, I have eyes.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p:
So has an Aſs, from whom thou differ'ſt not, but by thy Ears: thou wicker-bottle, edg-leſs knife; thou Ape of generation, whom Providence ſhuffled hither in an unthinking Age, for no ſuch fools are created now-a-days: Didſt thou dare to blaſt my Virtue, my Integrity, thou laughter of our ſex,
and foot-ball of thy own? If I were a man, I would cut that Carkaſs of thine into as ſmall a quantity as thy Wits; I'd make you an example.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Nay, now ſhe has got the whip-hand of us, the Devil's in her. Well, I muſt take another time, 'tis in vain to contend now.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What, is he gone? 'Sbud I'le after him, and have ſatisfaction, or I'le whip him through the Mid-riff, by Mars.

lg.l: Thus when extremes of fear too near advance,
Some Courtly God looks down and lends us chance;
Turns the great Scale, let's longing Lovers meet;
And dangers paſt, make coming Joys more ſweet.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: COme, prithee let's be gone; I wonder what delight thou canſt take in this Garden, a place ſo intolerably peſter'd with Flies and Fops.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: By St. Tavy, Fop was fery coot Diferſions, to Winny; there is fine tittle tattles, and pribbles and prabbles, that makes Winny laugh till her pones akes agen.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: This place is the Retreat of Lewdneſs, the very Mart of Debauchery: Here the raw Country-Fop treats the Town-Bully; the ſneaking Cuckold his ugly Wife, and more ugly Off ſpring; the Spindle-ſhank'd Prentice his dirty Drab, and the Court Fleſh-fly his Miſs of Quality.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: And is not all this fery coot Diferſions, look you? Pleſs us awll! ſure your plood is corrupted with Flegmaticks and Melancholies.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Here's ſome encouragement however: that ſmile ſhews they'r in a good humour.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: See, Madam, here's ſome of the company you wiſh'd for.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Are theſe fools? Pleſs us awll, how they ſtare at us?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: She begins already, I find we ſhall have a bleſſed entertainment.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Prithee have patience.

lg.l: When Beauty in the Conqueſt bears a part,
Who can have skill enough to guard a Heart?
When Impudence in man exceeds the Devil,
Who can have skill enough to make him civil?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: There's a reliſh for you my friend, you ſhall have more anon.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: An honourable Zeal to ſerve a Beauty, was ne're accounted Impudence till now: we are no Satyrs, Madam.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: If you had their hoofs, as you have their manners, 'twas the beſt name I could call you.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Nay, nay, no ſtrugling, for by St. Winifrid Hur will, and muſt be heard.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: I know not what ails me, but of late I have no mind to rail againſt this Wilding: ſure he wears ſome Charm about him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The Devil's in her: that ſuch a ſhape ſhou'd harbour ſo inſufferable a humour.
Madam, though I hate Intruſion, it wou'd appear a grand rudeneſs in me not to entertain you in this juncture; for a good Wit (like yours) ſhould never be alone.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: And no Wit like yours ſhould, Sir: and ſo your Servant.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Dam her, her Wit has Daggers in't, and every word ſhe ſpeaks ſtings like an Adder: Well; Come what will, I'le follow her, and rail victoriouſly this once, though I prove ever Dumb hereafter.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: What! is hur Cozen gone, and has left hur?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Gone into the next Walk, 'tis a piece of civility in her to give Lovers opportunity.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Opportunity's! Pleſs us awll, for what? you will not Raviſh hur, will you? nor rob Winny of precious Jewels and Virginities, I hope.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul but I will though, and yet do thee no harm neither: — Come, prithee be willing, and ſave the trouble.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: The Tevil ſhall have thee firſt; hur will not ſave the trouble, therefore let hur have liperties and freedoms, or hur will cry out, and ſcratch, and bite, and kick, and ſprawl; Oh heavens! what Raviſh hur — at theſe years? Would he were in earneſt, I vow. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Oh I Love a Ladies voice that cries out on ſuch an occaſion extremely: and as for biting and ſcratching, 'tis better than tickling to me, the greateſt motive to raiſe my appetite in the world: Come, come, you were made thus beautiful to be belov'd; and 'tis a ſin to let your Lover languiſh for what you once muſt part with, or be wretched.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Ay, put then there is Marriages in the caſe: Look you; if hur were Married, then let 'em Raviſh hur a Cods name.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Marriage! why, 'tis the Antidote of Love, the very thought on't makes me cold and ſpiritleſs: I'm ſtupid, numb'd now, that Damn'd word freezes more than the coldeſt blaſt in the North of Greenland.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Prea let hur go. This is a fery dull fellow, I ſwear. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: You kill me if you ſpeak on't: Come, come this way.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Why ſure hur will not force hur.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: I will not force thee: I know thou wilt conſent, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p:
Hur cannot, dare not, muſt not conſent; Oh, my heart, how it
peats — is there no Honours nor Faith in men? Let hur co now, hur will be kinder another time.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Oh, I dare not truſt to that, ſome peeviſh fit or other will happen, and then, like a true woman, you will recant, and perfidiouſly break your promiſe; and a man may as ſoon get Money of a Jew upon Charity, as a Lovefavour from a Woman, when ſhe's out of humour.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Why then hur thinks hur is in humours now?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: No, but I think you will be before the buſineſs is done; that's my comfort.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Prea do not fex hur thus: kind, ſweet Sir, upon hur knees hur pegs hur to let hur go.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Will you be kind then next time? Swear upon your Soul. —

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: And upon hur Soul's and Podies hur will.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: And love me?

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Teerly.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: And be ſo grateful to deny me nothing I ſhall ask?

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Nothing that you ſhall deſire.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: This civil kiſs then, and farewell: — nay go inſtantly from my ſight, for if. I look on thee, there is a Dancing Devil in that Eye would make me turn Apoſtate, ſpite of Ten thouſand Vows and Promiſes. Apart.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: A the Tevil take thee for ferv fools; what! believe what Woman ſays in ſuch caſes, and talk of kiſſes and civilities? Farewell; Well Winny's ſhall never teſire thy dull Converſations more upon hur Souls. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: When there are ſure hopes of a ſurrender, there is the leſs need of force; beſides, Compliance and Free-will is the Soul of enjoyment: for 'tis a folly for a man to ſnatch greedily a raw ill-dreſs'd morſel, when for a little patience a well-cook'd ſavoury Diſh will court his appetite, and is purpoſely prepar'd for him. How now, Tom! is ſhe gone?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Dam her: ſhe is got amongſt a Herd of She-Foxes yonder, and is not poſſibly to be hunted from 'em; but I have ſet my Footman to dog-where ſhe goes, and am firmly reſolv'd for another Tongue-combat.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: My little Welſh Rogue is gone too; well, ſome grand miſchief will certainly happen to me, for I'le tell thee what I did juſt now. — I miſs'd the critical minute, and let my ador'd creature go, meerly out of a high point of hohour: What think'ſt thou? is not this a damn'd Omen of more damn'd luck, ha?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: 'Tis, I confeſs, as uſual with thee to be ſo civil, as 'tis to ſay thy prayers; but vet the Omen may be propitious enough, all things conſider'd.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Dam conſideration, would I had her agen; but I muſt be civil, forſooth, and ſo loſe my Miſtreſs: Civil, and value punctilio's of honour and virtue: Virtue, that Vanity of women, and Bugbear of fools.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p:
Virtue, that was ſo civil to poſſeſs thy heart, which thou didſt not
deſire; and ſo uncivil to hinder thee •… om enjoying a Beauty, which thou did'ſt.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: True, by you Stars! curs'd, fooliſh plebeian notion.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha: How now! who comes here?

div.stage: Enter Sir Barnaby flauntingly, Dreſs'd like an Officer, with a Footman.

lg.l: Let the Roundheads Plot on,
Till at laſt they'r undone
By hurting their Brains to Decoy us.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Hah! what, my quondam Rabbi Achitophel, Sir Barnaby Whigg?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Captain Whigg, if you pleaſe, Sir:

lg.l: Let the Roundheads Plot on, &c.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ah, you are a precious Turn-coat Raſcal: What! now the Storm is coming, you are for the King, I warrant?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Ay, ay boy — thou'rt in the right: S'woones who ſhould I be elſe for, hoh? —

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: He bluſters, and pretends to Swear too.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: No faith, I'm but a learner yet; I can't mouth an Oath worth a farthing, for I have bin ſo us'd to uds-nigs, uds-chitterlings, and the like, that my mouth is quite ſpoil'd for Swearing; but I don't doubt in a little time. —

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: This upſtart in Debauchery, is wicked enough to Damn an Army.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: From a Saint to a Devil, is but an odd Converſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Peace: Tace; not a word of that: — If thou had'ſt the Pox, would'ſt thou love to hear on't? beſides, what I do, is not ſo much for my own ſake, as for my poor Wives.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Your Wife! your Whore you mean.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: She was my Whore once, 'tis true — but I have now Married her.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Lawfully are you ſure?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: So Parſon Clammy ſays: you know him.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: What is this Clammy?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: O, a fellow of the true tone and cant, and famous amongſt the longear'd Rout for his oily hand, goggle eyes, and ſtinking breath.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: His Doctrine was not very ſavoury, that's the truth on't, for all his double way of exerciſing.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: His double way! prithee what's that?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Why his holding forth to the Men all day, and to the Women all night; that I call his double way.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: A precious brother indeed.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Then the green Ribbon Club I find is now diſpers'd: pray, where's your late friend and brother Sir Miles Mutinons?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Where? why in Nowgate.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: How! Newgate! who has Impeach't him?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: I, I my ſelf, man: Impeach't him! and more than that, intend to hang him next Seſſions.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: A fine, friendly, Chriſtian-like Act, in troth.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Ay Gad — friend or father in ſuch a caſe: up they-go to ſave my own neck: I don't love hanging, for my part — others may.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well, thou art alter'd in thy nature, I ſee; prithee what Religion art?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Oh, Orthodox, good, ſound, ſubſtantial: I love Biſhops with all my heart; Gad they keep excellent Tables.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And 'tis for that, if the truth were known. Well, Sir, look to't, for if I find you change this Opinion.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: If you do, Hang me, Impeach, Carbonado, Fricaſee me: — I tell thee I am fix'd firm as a Rock; and ſo farewell. I have ten quart Bumpers to drink to the Kings Health to night, and they ſhall off as I'm an Orthodox Captain; and ſo a Pox of all Roundheads: Come away, boy.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Who dares truſt mankind that ſees this fellow? I am reſolv'd to have a trick upon him; I'le ſift him once more; my Footman ſhall be my Agent.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: And here opportunely he comes.

sp.speaker: Footm.
sp.p: Sir, I dogg'd my Lady Lofty to the Captains houſe, and heard her order her Footman to fetch the Coach thither.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why then hey for a tryal of Skill: Come friend; Sirrha come you hither too, you muſt do a bus'neſs for me: You can Act a Scotch Prieſt, can't you, ſirrha?

sp.speaker: Footm.
sp.p: Bread a Gad, Can I, Sir? and weel too.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Townly in Womens Cloaths, led in by Captain Porpuſs, and Boy after.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: FAir Lady, welcome aboard, heartily welcome, as a man may ſay: what, ho, there in the Cook-room? where's my Wife? have a little patience, Madam, and I'le fetch her inſtantly. —

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: 'Sdeath how I tremble?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Oones, what a ſtrapping Quean's this! what a Bulk ſhe bears! and true Flemiſh built, I ſee that, by her Forecaſtle: Gad ſhe's a brave Frigot, and by Caſtor and Pollux I'le give her a Broadſide preſently.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: The Devil cram thee into one of thy own Guns, and ſhoot thee off at the Turks, e're thou liv'ſt to fright •… e ſo agen.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Where did you meet him, Sir? I'm ſure he did not come by me.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: A Pox on him, at the Garden-gate, juſt as I was whiſtling to get in; and ſeeing me peep about, he bluntly ask'd me who I would ſpeak with? At that word I gave a ſtart, that I believe would have ſhook off Nature from a weaker conſtitution, and made ſhift to tell him, his Wife; and (I thank him) he is now going to fetch her to me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The merchandize had need be good, I'm ſure you venture hard.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Sirrha I had no way to get to her, but by this diſguize: but, d'ee hear ſirrha, go you inſtantly to my 'tother Miſtreſs, the Lady Millicent, and deſire her to meet me at Lockets this evening; and excuſe my abſence, and tell her I'm involv'd in a damnable Suit of Law, and have this day had a Tryal before the Judges in Weſtminſter-Hall: you Dog, you could tell a lye handſomely once with a Pox to you.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O, Sir, never doubt me, I'm ſtill Maſter of my faculty.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: I hope I ſhall be Miſtreſs of mine, if I continue in this habit two hours longer. — A pretty, decent Garb this faith, and very proper to the bus'neſs; for a Petticoat is as neceſſary for one that deſigns to run to another mans Wife, as Breeches are for a woman that intends to run from her Husband: But hark! here they come; now to my poſture.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Here is my Spouſe ready to embrace thee, fair Syren of the Rocks.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Madam, I beg your Ladyſhips pardon, I have forgot you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What's that! forgot her?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Hell and the Devil! I ſhall be betray'd; ſhe does not know me. Forget me, Madam? what, your dear Siſter? Whiſpers.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: O, dear Madam! is it you? I beg your pardon a thouſand times; my dear (dear) Siſter!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Oh! is your memory come agen? forget her Quotha! that's a good Jeſt indeed.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: The ſolace of my youth, ſoul of my joys, my life, my heart, my dear, dear, ſweet, charming —

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ah poor Rogues, they make my mouth water to ſee 'em: 'Sbud, Madam, I'm but a rough-hew'n Courtier; I cannot prate, nor complement, nor chatter fragments of Damn'd Poetry, not I. — But if you will have a taſte of my skill, you ſhall: you ſhall hear me ſay, and Box my Compaſs.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Plague that will be inſufferable. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Nore, Nore and by Eaſt, Nore, Nore-Eaſt, Nore-Eaſt and by Nore, Nore-Eaſt: Nore Eaſt and by Eaſt, Eaſt, Nore-Eaſt, Eaſt and by Nore, Eaſt: Eaſt and by Sou, Eaſt, Sou-Eaſt, Sou-Eaſt and by Eaſt, Sou-Eaſt: Sou-Eaſt and by Sou, Sou, Sou-Eaſt, Sou and by Eaſt: Sou, Sou and by Weſt, Sou, Sou-Weſt, Sou-Weſt and by Sou, Sou-Weſt: Sou Weſt and by Weſt, Weſt, Sou-Weſt, Weſt and by Sou, Weſt; Weſt and by Nore, Weſt, Nore-Weſt, Nore-Weſt and
by Weſt, Nore-Weſt: Nore-Weſt and by Nore, Nore, Nore-Weſt, Nore and by Weſt, Nore.

sp.speaker: Rachell.
sp.p: I muſt have a trick to get this old Porpuſs out of the way, Sir; Captain Bluſter has ſent his Man to deſire your company at the Three Cranes about earneſt bus'neſs.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Bus'neſs! a Pox of his bus'neſs, what does he trouble me for? Cannot he get a Commiſſion for Convoy, cheat the King, and ſo forth without me: Prithee tell him I'm engag'd here with this Fairy, this Cherubin has engag'd me: Gads-bud, well remembred, I'le ſecure you both my ſelf till I come agen; faith here's an Alcove, the beſt in the World for that bus'neſs: Come, Madam, nay no drawing back; by Mars 'tis a frolick, and I am reſolv'd to have my humour.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: I ſhall laugh, I ſhall never contain my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Spouſe, be ſure you be kind to her; d'ee hear; give her a Buſs for me: D'ee ſmile, Rogue? d'ee ſmile? I'le be with you preſently, ſaith: Get you in; go, get you in: Locks 'em in. So, if my bus'neſs is not done now, the Devil's in't, for I'm ſure of her till my return; then, if ſhe yields upon a fair Summons, ſo; if not, I'le blow up her upper Deck, by Jove; I'me a true Tarpawlin; I'me for no Parlies. But now I'le go to the Three Cranes, and ſee for Captain Bluſter.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: The old Blunderbuſs is gone, though long firſt; I have bin ſtow'd up in a Cole-hole under the Stairs for theſe two hours; the Spiders and I have Rooſted together only to watch his going out; for I am reſolv'd to know the meaning of his Wives laſt project, for the Devil take me if I underſtood her; and who knows but it might be a Love-trick, a Sham, only to blind her Husbands eyes; I'm ſure I us'd to be a lucky Dog at theſe matters. Hark! ſure I hear her voice.

sp.speaker: Within. Livia.
sp.p: Prithee let us laugh: I ſwear this was the pleaſanteſt Adventure I ever knew; Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Within. Townly.
sp.p: To bubble your Husband too, Madam, and make him the Procurer; Ha, ha, ha: Oh I could laugh eternally.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: The Devil! what's this I hear? Townly in the Alcove?

sp.speaker: Within. Townly.
sp.p: And then to gull that Coxcomb, Sir Walter, of his Miſtreſs too, that Tool of Knighthood, that Copper-farthing with the Kings ſtamp on't; to cheat him too is a true Scene of pleaſure; Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Is it ſo, damn'd Raſcals? O, for a Piſtol now charg'd with white Powder, that I might kill 'em both, and make no noiſe on't.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Could the Inſect imagine I lov'd him! what I love a fool?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Fool! Ha, ha, ha; oh the damnable ignorance of Women.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I have bin at the Three Cranes, and the Devil of any one is there to ſpeak with me: ſure the Jilt abuſes me.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: The Captain! ſo, now for revenge: now Jilt, now Raſcal, I'le requite your treachery: now ſhew a Jugling-trick and vaniſh: now ſhoot (like Atoms) through the key-hole, or like Mice under the door, if you can; I'le watch you, faith.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How now! uds bud what's here? this damn'd Coxcomb-Knight noſing my game already? what bus'neſs have you here, Sir, ha?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Huſh man, ſpeak lower; and if you have any regard to your honour, now look about you, for to my knowledge there is in that Alcove a perſon with your Wife, whom —

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Whom perhaps you love? Oones I love her too, make your beſt on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Piſh, prithee have patience, and hear me: why thou think'ſt thou'rt in a Storm ſure by this bluſtering and ſwearing: I tell thee there is a perſon in that Alcove — that —

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That I deſire ſhould continue there ſtill.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Continue, Sir! what, with your Wife, Sir?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: With my Wife, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: What, Townly! that Villain Townly?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hey day! Townly! Ha, ha, ha, the fool's diſtracted; prithee is Townly a Man or a Woman, ha?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Nay ſhe can beſt tell by this time.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I'm a Cuckold, Ha, ha, ha, I'm a Cuckold, and Townly is with her, Ha, ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: What a Pox d'ee laugh at? I tell you he is with her, I heard his voice.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, Sir, let him be there, he'l do no hurt, Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Do her no hurt? is the Devil in him? why, believe your eyes then; I'le open the door.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sir, ſtand off, I'le not have 'em diſturb'd, 'tis not civil.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Not civil! a Pox — he's bewitch'd ſure; what, to be reveng'd of a man that lies with your Wife, not civil?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I ſay, not civil, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Then you allow it?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I will allow any thing they do.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: And you ſaw 'em go in?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ay, Sir; and more than that, I lock'd 'em in, and here's the key.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: One is too little; all the Devils have poſſeſs'd him: and you will be a Cuckold then? you are reſolv'd on't?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Now you lye, Sir, and ſo I lower your top-fail; go, ſcud away quickly, or (d'ee hear) I ſhall grapple, I ſhall board you; by this hand I ſhall, Sir Watt.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Why, Captain, are you mad? Do but hear me mun.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Away I ſay, before Durandon be unſheath'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: I tell you I heard him there; what a Devil ails him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I ſhall ſwinge you confoundedly if you ſtay.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Let me but open the door, and if I fly —

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ho, Bounce: there's a Gun then. Bounce: keep your Deck hoh.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: What a Devil ails him? why, Captain! —

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hey boys, ſhe flies — Scowr, ſcowr, ſcowr; Runs him out. ſo, ſo, now the fool's gone, come out Chickens, come; Ʋnlocks the door. and how does my Miſtreſs do? ha! what almoſt tyr'd I warrant.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir, I'le ſtay another hour if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Good faith no ſuch matter, l've a cup of Sack within came from Teneriff; come, we'l go and make a Collation, and ſing, and kiſs, and be merry; come ſweet Pinnace: Gadzooks ſhe has the fineſt Buttocks; come Duck, come.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Thus far all is ſerene and clear; pray heav'n no Storm happen hereafter, for I muſt venture to go and part 'em, though I find it will be di •… icult: Call within, Livia, my Dear. Hark! 'tis my Lady Lofty's voice. But I muſt beg her pardon now, I'm engag'd.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Livia, Livia, where are you?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: An ill-natur'd beauty deſerves to want company; who is't you ſeek?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: 'Tis my misfortune to find one I don't ſeek always.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Your notion is as treacherous as your humour: you would find me, I know you are in love with me.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Obliging Vanity; for what I pray?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: My Perſon, my Humour, Language and Wit; all which you have the vanity to believe you can beſt judg of.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Yes, ſo well judg, to know your deficiency in either of theſe, I thank my Stars.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Can you diſprove me?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Do.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Firſt for your Perſon then.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come, what of that?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Heav'n keep me from prophaning it; 'tis a lend, foppiſh, cenſorious, noiſy perſon, a meer piece of puff-paſt, a fleſh-bag, that carries God a'mighty's fool to the Worlds great Mart, there ſells him to the Devil by Inch of Candle for a Suburo Whore, and a Bottle of Champaign.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: So, my Language?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: 'Tis more barbarous than Dutch; your words are creeping, the very Reptils of Language, and one would gueſs your Tutor was a Waterman.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Very well. My Wit?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Premeditation only; you are like a narrow-neck'd Bottle haſtily turn'd downwards; upon ſurprize one can get nothing out of you. You, Sir, (amongſt all men) ſhould love Plays, and pay double when you go; for 'twas a Comedy, and not a Colledge that ſet you up for a Wit.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Excellent! Gad ſhe has put me into a ſweat. If abuſive railing may paſs for Wit, Madam, I confeſs, you have ſhewn ſome now.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: What! and to one I'm in love withall? Conſider, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nay, do you conſider, Madam, you that are the very Mint of falſhood, in whoſe face treachery and ſmiles are promiſcuouſly joyn'd to cheat the adventurous fool that comes to barter — You are —

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: You are.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nay, Gad, now you ſhall hear what you are, [if I have a heart to ſpeak it. Aſide.
You are one that nature doggedly deſign'd a plague to vex mankind: have at you in Verſe, y' faith.

lg.l: Your Virtue, which as little has
Of Beauty as your face,
Was giv'n not as a bleſſing, but a guide
For men to ſee your vanity and pride.
Had you bin perfect, as juſt heav'n Decreed with care you ſhould not be,
I bluſh to think, how your Diſdain would feed upon mortality.
But ſince you are not good, nor kind, nor wiſe, whence can this pride ariſe,
That makes beſt graces ſeem Deformities.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: So: theſe I dare ſwear, Sir, are the fruits of your own Muſe by their little wit, and much ill nature: and, I vow, I am ſo ill at Rhiming, that I have only one poor Couplet to return by way of Anſwer.

lg.l: Y'are Pleaſure's ſlave, whoſe heart wild paſſions rule;
To fools a Wit, but the witty Womans fool.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: 'Sdeath I can hold out no longer: If ſo many graces appear when ſhe's angry, what muſt ſhe be when pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Come, Sir, your Repartee — what! are you grown dull o'th' ſuddain?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I ſee then, Madam, you'l never have done: Come, ſpeak on.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: I take no pride in ſpeaking of this ſubject.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: That you glory to affront our Sex, I have prov'd by my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: When you glory to begin Diſcourſes of this nature, 'tis rather you that give the affront.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Meer deſign, upon my ſoul, on my ſide, and only to try your humour and wit: why ſhould we differ thus, Madam, and waſte thoſe hours in tedious and unpleaſant wranglings, that ſhould be ſpent in the contrary extreme, kind wit, obliging looks, and tender notions.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: And would you kill your Darling Satyr then? Satyr, your boſomfriend! and (if you are to ſpeak to a Woman) the very key of your Eloquence, and ſoul of your Wit and Fancy.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Madam, this Satyr you ſpeak of is a Cupid, bleſs'd, ſweet, and charming: you ſaw it only in Diſguiſe, which now pull'd off, the God himſelf appears, kind, beautiful, and young, to glad my heart with love and tender paſſion.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Love! of what in the name of Virtue?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Of you. [Heav'n be prais'd 'tis out at laſt. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Of me! Ha, ha, ha: I ſwear you'r a fool then.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I am ſo, who can help it; yet ſtill I muſt love on.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Swear.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: By this dear hand.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Agen.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Theſe dazling lovely eyes, that pretty powting lip, that Angels face, and Wit more ſacred, I do; ſo help me Love, and ſo may I thrive and proſper.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: You have brought your ſelf into a fine condition.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The happieſt and moſt ſacred of my life. Loves intire ſelf is here: my Heart's his Pallace, and every artery and vein about me is full of Love, nothing but Love: Does not the ſympathetick power Charm you? Do you not feel him, Madam?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: A little.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: It will be more e're long: the Deity is now juſt blowing up the Coles that are to Thaw that proud, hard, frozen heart; I know it will be mine: Come, baniſh (Madam) the Virgins pride and coyneſs, and let the Goddeſs, like her ſelf, appear: Say then you love, you will; ſay inſtantly, for every word againſt it carries Fate.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Well, Sir, to ſave your life I will; but —

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ah dear, charming, heav'nly creature!

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Nay, hear me out; for it concerns you nearly, beſure you are conſtant: I ſay, be ſure you are, for I am monſtrous paſſionate, and extremely jealous, and hate a Rival ev'n to Death and Hell; take heed to oblige in this, and then —

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Is there a pleaſure like Content in Love? No, 'tis impoſſible.

lg.l: The Warriour ſeeks the paths where Honour trod,
The Miſer courts the wealthy dazling God.
But th' Lover ſtill the greateſt joy doth know,
By Beauty bleſs'd, gains Paradiſe below.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: THis comes of Railing, Tom: Did I not prognoſticate the reſult of this buſineſs? have I not hourly cultivated thee with that old phraſe, Amantium irae Amoris? and art thou ſnapt at laſt? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You are merry, Sir; but he that laughs when there is no Jeſt, is like one that has a damn'd ſerious face, but no buſineſs, 'tis equally ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, to rail one ſelf into a paſſion, is the oddeſt method I ever knew; 'tis a fit ſubject for a Scene; I intend to commend it to a Poet of my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Take heed, and pray that I get thee not at an advantage; for if I do, I will be a perpetual plague to thee. A Coward that by chance has won a prize, brags not ſo much as I will Tyrannize.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; but ſee yonder's your man diſguis'd, coming with Sir Barnaby: I find the trick takes.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The Rogue has dreſs'd himſelf like a Dominican; now for a Tryal of my Roundheads Orthodox-honeſty; I believe I ſhall find him a Recreant-Knight. Come, let's retire, and obſerve.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: How, Father? a Baſſa's Widow, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: Gud feth is ſhe, Sir, and Neice tal the Grand Vizier.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: What, and in Love with me?

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: Sick, Sir, even to death for you; nay, if ſhe were not almoſt paſt recovery, ye ſhou'd not ſo ſoon ha' known it, Sir; poor Lady, ſhe was bred from an Infant under my Guardianſhip; I was her Confeſſor at Rome; and lately being enjoyn'd a Pennance here into England to viſit St. Coleman's Tomb; 'tis her hard fate to fall in love, Sir; nay, is likely to throw away a vaſt fortune upon a Heretick, a Proteſtant I fear; and if ſo, ſhe's undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Od's heart here's luck now: Nay, good Father ſay not ſo, I am her Vaſſal, her humble ſlave, her dog, any thing.

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, there may be love enough; and though you are Married, we can get a Diſpenſation: but where's the Bleſſing? where's the Sanctification? Pray what Religion are ye, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: So, there' the Choak-pear; now liſten. Peeping.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: What Religion am I? hum? why, faith, to tell thee the truth, Father, I am — hum — Of what Religion am I, d' you ſay?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ah! damn'd Rogue, now the word Orthodox can't get out of's mouth.

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, what Sect? what Opinion?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Opinion? why, look Father, I'me of Opinion that — but by the way firſt, if I may be ſo bold, pray what Eſtate has this Lady? you ſay ſhe's very rich.

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: Why, Sir, if you happen to prove an honeſt, godly Roman Catholick, ſhe ſhall have Ten thouſand pounds; but if you are a Proteſtant — Angrily.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Not I man, I'me no Proteſtant, not I, nor never was, nor never will be, not I — 'Sbud Ten thouſand pounds. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: Or own any Allegiance or Power but his Holineſs the Pope, and See of Rome.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Not I, faith, the Pope's a very worthy, civil Gentleman; and for my part, I ever lov'd and honour'd him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: So thou wou'dſt the Devil if he brought but Money enough.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Without doubt, and own him, the ſame civil, worthy Perſon.

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: Son, Son, I fear you are not ſound at heart; I fear the weed of Hereſie has infected you, and you cannot diſpence with our Doctrine.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Piſh, I can I tell thee with all my heart man, the Doctrine's a good Doctrine; yes, faith, I like the humour of't well enough, and will diſpence with't, bate me but the wearing of a hair Shirt, and uſing father Whitebread's unconſcionable Cat of Nine-tails.

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: Not for the World, Sir; to what height wou'd that fleſh riſe, were it not ſometimes Diſciplin'd? you are full of ſin, Son, Fat, fat, very fat.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Portly, portly, like the Ancient Britiſh Race, a Veſſel of choice Wares, a Man of Kidney.

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: See how Fate orders things; I never cou'd perſwade this Wiſe Lady to love a Lean man: by St. Andrew ſhe never cou'd endure 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Gad ſhe's a witty Woman, a moſt ingenious perſon I warrant her: and Ten thouſand pounds too! — Uds bud there's a Sum, there's luck, there's fortune: Go thy ways brother Fat, Gad thou'rt a brave fellow: but, Father, where is ſhe, Father? I'me impatient; let me fix; let me ſee her.

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: Firſt fix your faith, Sir; here are your Beads, the Conſecrated tokens of your Converſion; be conſtant, and uſe 'em well; pray often, then be happy.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Faith I'le do what I can; but, Father, you'l do me a very great favour to oblige me with half a ſcore good taking prayers: for to deal ingenuouſly with you, I am at preſent a little out of ſorts; you know we Soldiers are ſeldom very devout.

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: My care ſhall ſtill attend you, Sir, — Gud feth. —

div.stage: Enter a Seaman with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Seaman.
sp.p: For Father Sawney, theſe from Rhodes.

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: Hah! and come in moſt happy time from her Uncle the Baſſa, without whoſe conſent ſhe has formerly Vow'd not to Marry: and this Letter doubtleſs contains his pleaſure.

p.q: Since my Neice is driven to ſuch extremity, and that her ill fortune obliges her to Love one whoſe Nation I hate; I am forc't to conſent to't, but upon theſe two Conditions: Firſt, that he be found of Quality; and, ſecondly, that he immediately turn Muſſelman, or elſe my Curſe and Mahomets follow her.

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: Woons what's here! why, this is worſt of all, baſe, irreligious, worſe, worſe than any thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: What? what's that? what, does he ſay I muſt turn Muſtardman?

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: Oh! more impious, barbarous, far beyond the vaineſt of all Sects and Hereſies, a Fiend, a Musſle-man.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Musſleman! what a Fiſherman?

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: Worſe, worſe ſtill, far more criminal than the baſeſt of Functions; he ſays you muſt never Marry his Neice, unleſs you turn Turk.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Turk! Well, well, ſince it can't be help't, I'le turn Turk, man, Jew, Moor, Graecian, any thing: Pox on't, I'le not loſe a Lady, and ſuch a ſum for the ſake of any Religion under the Sun, by Mahomet not I. —

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: But does not your Conſcience prick you a little?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Not a jot, faith. Why you old fool, our Conſcience is our Intereſt always, and I have not been a Rebel ſo long ſure to have any ſqueamiſh fits at theſe years.

sp.speaker: Seaman.
sp.p: Our Expreſs from the Levant brings word of a Fleet of Turkiſhmen coming hither, and 'tis ſuppos'd upon ſome great deſign.

sp.speaker: Swift.
sp.p: There's your way, Son; and ſince it muſt be ſo, obey Mahomet; ſight for the Grand Signior, and win the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: I'le do't by Alha, by Mahomet I will; I'le go preſently and corrupt my Men; ſome with bribes, ſome with promiſes and fair words, others with preferments: Then ſow Sedition 'mongſt the Mobile, win 'em with Pots of Ale, and Peny Loaſs, to commit Ryots, Murders; there's your Policy! I'le do't I ſay; I'me ſure I'me ſafe, for my Aſtrologer has ſecur'd my life, therefore I'le go on; and when Signior Turk and I plunder the City, the Lady Mine, and Mine the Potent Bullion, then Grandſire Grey-beard ſhalt thou be my Baſſa.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But e're that happen, grand Raſeal, you ſhall be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Wilding! then I'me undone, and all the Stars have fail'd me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p:
By Mahomet have they, and moſt baſely too; Thou Turn Coat ſlave, where's your Orthodox Opinion now, your Healths in Ten quart Bumpers to the King? you are now firſt for the Pope, and then for Mahomet, either, or any ſide, ſo there's but Money: Plunder the City, raiſe the Mobile, Plot with a
Prieſt here, otherwiſe call'd my Foot-man, and Coach-man the Tarpawlin: What think you now, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: His Foot-man! was ever Politician ſo o're-reacht.

sp.speaker: Juſtice.
sp.p: Secure him as a Traytor, and carry him to my houſe, where I'le take his Examination, and accordingly make his Mittimus to Newgate.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Well, I ſee I muſt be hang'd, and there's an end of't; but my Aſtrologer's a damn'd Dog for telling me I ſhou'd be a Duke though. But come, ſince it can't be help't, I'le e'en ſay my prayers, and ſuffer patiently, as the reſt of my Tribe have done before me.

sp.speaker: Juſtice.
sp.p: Away, away with him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a Raſcal?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Yes, Thouſands in their hearts; but ſome are ſtanch Politicians with a Pox to 'em.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Rogues that ſpeak Treaſon by alluſion and ſmile; a new way they have got, wou'd there were a new way of hanging too: but come, 'tis late, my Miſtreſs treats to night, thou ſhalt ſup with me there.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Your Miſtreſs! oh, is it come to that?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and ſhall continue ſo, I'm now Converted.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Was not that Mr. Wildings Coach that went away juſt as we came in.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, and I heard him bid drive to my Lady Lofty's.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Pray heav'n he did not ſee me: Friend, your Maſter is a very naughty perſon to occaſion me to venture my reputation in ſuch a cenſorious place.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: He'l repair that fault, Madam, when he delivers his buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Lord, what an odious houſe 'tis! ſough, what a ſtink is here of Tobacco? Can this be a place of pleaſure for men of ſenſe?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Now, Madam, I hope you will believe me: here's my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: This he? what, and Metamorphos'd to an Exchange-Wench?

sp.speaker: Townly.

lg.l: So Jove, the Sire of all the Gods above,
Transform'd himſelf to gain Europa's Love.

sp.p: Madam, I ſee you'r a Woman of Honour by being thus punctual, and ought to be truſted another time.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I doubt that's more than I can ſafely ſay of you; I hope your Lawbuſineſs is ended, Sir?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Yes, I have overthrown my Adverſary at laſt; but we had a long bout of't firſt, faith.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: And you came juſt now from Weſtminſter-Hall in this garb?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: No Child, in this garb, no: I only devis'd this to be ſecure from diſcovery; for if I am not miſtaken, I ſaw Sir Walter below in a Ground-room; and he and I are fallen out of late.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Sir Walter! What a fright am I in? are you ſure he did not ſee me?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: No, nor me neither; he was very buſie playing at Tick-tack with one of the Drawers.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, the Porter has brought your Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: So, ſo that's well: Come, ſirrah, help me to Unrig: Pull off theſe damn'd Cobweb-Caps here, and give me my Peruke.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: And did you really diſguiſe your ſelf thus for my ſake?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul did I; and if you don't think this a proof of my Love and Conſtancy, Gad, Madam, you're ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Nay, rather than be thought ſo, I will believe you.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: You have reaſon I think; you know I hate Lying. Come, ſirrah, give me my Coat.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I dogg'd my beloved Pinnace to this houſe, and have now loſt her: 'Sbud I'me afraid ſhe's no better than a Fireſhip, and ten to one comes here to be Man'd. How now! who are theſe?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Dammee, Sir, is this civil to intrude? Hah! the Captain!

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Oh! fatal Chance!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Oones, what's here a Man! Oh! I'me undone! abus'd! a Cuckold! oh! damn'd Whore, what turn'd to a Man?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: How! the Captain? nay, then all's diſcover'd; but I'le run and Inform Madam Livia, it may be ſhe may help my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A Hermophrodite, a Man! Oh! Villain, I'le give thee a Chace Gun preſently, a damn'd Son of a Whore.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: A Man! what d' you mean, Sir? why I'me a Woman I aſſure you, and a near Relation of this Lady's, upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What, a Woman?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Yes, and this habit is only a preparation for a Maſquerade to night; pray reform your Error, and do not fright me, Sir; I tell you I'me a Woman.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'Sbud ſhow, ſhow, I'le not believe you unleſs you ſhow.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: 'Sdeath what ſhall I do; nay more than that, Sir, upon my Honour I'me quick with Child.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How, Quick! that's very likely: Oh! Dolt, Dunce, Fool, not to perceive the cheat before. Quick in the Devil's name.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: This is ſtrange-rudeneſs, Sir, to one you never ſaw before.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, no, I did not bring my Wife to you this afternoon, did I?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: How, bring his Wife to him?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: To me, Sir? Oh! the Devil now all comes out. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, no, nor like a Sea-Calf as I was, I did not lock ye both up together in the Alcove, did I?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: 'Tis plain now, this diſguiſe was not meant to me, but Livia. Oh! perjur'd Traytor!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That I am a Cuckold, is moſt certain and a notorious Cuckold, and by my own contrivance too; had I been tranſlated to a Sea horſe, a Dog, a Calf, or any beaſt but that, I ſhou'd have been contented: but a Sea-Cuckold, 'sbud 'tis the moſt horrid Monſter it has.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: A Cuckold! why then, Sir, upon my faith I'me incapacitated for any ſuch buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A plague of your Capacity, I'le ſcowr your Midſhips preſently; thus, Sir, and thus Monſieur Rampant.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: How now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A Raſcal, a Cheat, a Cuckold-making Villain.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: How, Townly?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What, Townly? Oh! Damn'd Rogue, is't he all this while too?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: So, I've made a fine buſineſs on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Oh, Traytor! have we catcht you at laſt? Mawl him, Captain, Mawl him, he has Mawl'd you in the perſon of your Wife, to my knowledge. Hah! what's there my Spouſe too!

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: My Husband! Oh! curſt minute!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nay, he has mawl'd us both if the truth were known.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: My Wife found with him in an Eating alias Bawdy-houſe: Ay, 'tis evident now I'me a Cuckold both ways.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: However this Horn of mine ſhall knock his brains out.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: 'Sdeath I ſhall be Murder'd.

sp.speaker: 1 Offic.
sp.p: Here he is: Sir, I arreſt you at the Suit of Timothy Turpentine, in an Action of 500 l. Come, you muſt along with me.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Sir Timothy Turpentine? what a Pox is the meaning of this? I know no ſuch man: 'Tis Livia's hand; oh! the dear Creature.

sp.q: I queſtion whether you deſerve this; however, knowing your neceſſity, I have contriv'd to get you off; meet me at the corner of the next Street, and hereafter (if poſſibly your ſex can) be grateful.

sp.speaker: 1 Offic.
sp.p: Sir we are not us'd to delay; come, Brother, take him away.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Ay, and the Devil go with him▪

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, ſtay till I put on my Breeches, and I'le obey your Authority.

sp.speaker: 1 Offic.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, we'l take care of the Breeches, never fear: Come away, away.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No remedy, no revenge upon this Raſcal; have I boarded and took a Galiaſs of the Turks with 800 Men in her, to loſe my Honour here at home by a damn'd Fly-boat, with one Gun, a Fiſherman, a Flap-Dragon, a Plague upon his Capacity.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: This comes of Pimping, Captain; you muſt keep the door; 'twas not civil to diſturb 'em; a fine time to uſe manners in, by my troth: And a man of ſenſe, as I was, was not to be believ'd; your own Judgment, forſooth, muſt paſs, not knowing that 'tis as unnatural for a true Tarpawlin to have Wit, as a true Wit to have Money.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: This comes of Matrimony. On my Conſcience I had been an Admiral before now, if it had not been for a damn'd Wiſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Come, prithee let's go and make our ſelves drunk to put us in heart. 'Tis ſome comfort to me however, to know that this bluſt'ring fool is a Cuckold as well as my ſelf. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A Quean, a Jilt; Oons I'le go home and flea her.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: And ſo will I mine: and, Captain, doſt hear, we'l have two pair of Gloves made of their skins, and make a preſent of 'em to the Devil, to keep us from any more ſuch bargains.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: With all my heart, Gads bud.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Give me the Pomatums and her Night-gloves; her hands have bin fery exceeding rough all this day.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: There has been a ſharp Air, Madam.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Got pleſs me, how pale her looks! It has made her lips chap too.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: All will be ſmooth and beautiful to morrow, Madam.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p:
No, I vow my pewties, I think, is in decays, as Moons in Wanes, or Flowers in Autumns. Rachels, how doſt thou like me in theſe Dreſſes? ſhould'ſt
thou have heart-burnings and paſſions for me, if thou wert a Gentlemans, hah?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: I wou'd I were one to put you to the proof.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Nay, without doubt theſe Pinners muſt be pecoming in beds, where there is good faces, look you; but what nauceous, ugly Night-dreſſes the men have, as got pleſs me; I never ſee a mans with his Crop-ears and his Night-caps, but I think upon crete Rogue, one Shinkin, ap Powell, ap Shone, ap Davy, ap Cadwaller, that was hang'd in Montgomery.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Will not Mr. Benedick go down with you, Madam? he, I hope, has a face that wou'd ſet off any Dreſs.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Dull faces is the worſt of all I vow, he is the fery Snail of his Sex, and much fitter for Lawyers, than Lovers; he wou'd loſe Miſtreſs for punctilio's, like a ſilly Rogues; and as, got ſave me, he that loſes one critical minute, ſhou'd never be happy by another for Winifrid.

sp.speaker: Rach.
