sp.p: I ever took him for a brisker man than to loſe any Love-occaſion.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Fery good, then you do not know him ſo well as I, Rachels; peſides, he has put wrongs and affronts upon Winny; and when her Welſh pload's up, Gads plut Revenges ſhall follow: Therefore, Rachels, perſure you perform my Orders.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: I have made ready the Hanging-bed, Madam, and Oyl'd the Cords and Pulleys, as you bid me, but am wholly ignorant of your deſign.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Deſigns is cood and fertuous, I wou'd expoſe leud fellows to Eyes and Obſervations, and Jeers and Laughters, look you: Heark what noiſe is that! 'tis he I hope: and now for Welſh tricks and fallacies.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Moſt certainly he has diſcover'd us, for he ſaw us take Coach.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: And, Madam, are you ſure he purſu'd you hither?

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Ah! too ſure, Madam, he's at the door by this time; and being almoſt drunk, is poſſeſt with the ſtrangeſt fury and ill-nature, that unleſs you conceal me, who knows what his Barbarity may incite him to. Ah! Madam, Heav'n keep you from ſuch a Husband.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Ah! Dear cunning Creature! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: If theſe are the bleſſings incident to ſuch a life, I think the Prayer is neceſſary. Come, Madam, be comforted, and all the aſſiſtance I can lend you be ſure of. Poor ſoul, ſhe weeps extremely.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Weep! I, Mill-ſtones.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: You are not involv'd in this buſineſs; I hope, Sir, the Captain has no reaſon to extend his rage to you.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Not to me, 'dsheart I am plung'd deepeſt of all, Madam; he deſigns to cut my Throat, to Stab, to Piſtol me only for taking her part.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Madam, that door opens into a private, back Apartment; go and lock your ſelf in, whilſt I try if I can pacifie him: Hark! I think I hear him, in, in quickly: Nay, not you, Sir, I tell you 'tis a private Apartment, and not fit to entertain men.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Entertainment! The Devil take me, Madam, if I expect any.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: You'l not be rude I hope, Sir; pray come back, I wonder what you take me for.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Take thee for? why a good, fair, charming: Ah! Plague here ſhall I ſtand chatting punctilio's till I have a Bullet lodg'd in my head. For Heav'ns ſake, Madam; if not there, ſhow me ſome other place; for if he ſees me, I'me undone.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Oh! you can ſhift, Sir, you can ſhift; your ſex is excellent at it; and were you diſtreſs'd, I know cou'd climb a Chimney as dextrouſly as e're a black boy in Shoreditch.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Yes, choak't with Soot, e're I got half way, come tumbling down like a ſmoak't Flitch of Bacon.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Or upon occaſion to ſhow your Agility, leap from a Window; theſe are large, and wide, Sir, and fit for ſuch a purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Ay, and high enough to break ones neck too; 'Sdeath, Madam, d' you make a Gib-Cat of me, and think I can leap three Stories, and pitch upon all four; Fye, fye, I beſeech you have Charity.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: What, lock you up in the dark with another mans Wife; a very decent piece of Charity indeed: but by this fear of yours, Sir, I gueſs you to be ſome Criminal; I have heard ſhe had a Gallant; and now I think on't, it may be you are the Man.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Now a lucky lye to help me off, or I'me ruin'd: Tom Wilding, Madam, indeed was ſuſpected: but for my part, I never had ſuch good fortune, I.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: What is't he ſays, Wilding? who, Sir? Pray that agen.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Mr. Wilding, Madam, a witty man, and the beſt at a Wheadle and Town-Gallantry of any one I know.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Perjur'd Traytor! how oft has he ſwore he never Lov'd any one but me? And, Sir, are you ſure he is the man?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Madam, why all the Town knows it: I know he's too cunning to confeſs any thing: Come, dear Madam, ſome Lobby or Cloſet, ſomething Hark! what noiſe is that?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: There is no Faith in man; none, none I ſwear; for when they vow, they lye; and if they weep, 'tis Crocodile-like, after they have done a miſchief. Once more then farewell, ſoft paſſion, and all my tide of Love now turn to Anger.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, Madam, — What gone at laſt, and left me, the Devil's in theſe Virtuous Women, they are ever ill-natur'd. An honeſt, good-humour'd Whore wou'd have been damn'd e're ſhe wou'd have left a Man ſo, but wou'd have found ſome hole or other to put one in. Well, here's hangings however, Gad I'le creep like a Rat in here, ſince there is no other hopes.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Is it poſſible there can be ſuch Treachery? are you ſure you ſaw him here with Livia? Angrily.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Mr. Townly is a Man ſo generally known, Madam, that you need not fear my miſtake.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: 'Tis plain now, the Arreſt was only a trick of hers to get him off; Oh! ſubtle Devil, ſhe out-wits me every way. Well, bring me but to him, and I have my wiſh: there's a Purſe for thee; an Earneſt of a greater reward, if I find thou canſt keep a ſecret.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: So theſe are the infallible keys that unlock the Conſciences of all my Function: This is certainly one of Townly's conveniencies; a Miſs of Quality, as he calls 'em, that is grown jealous, has dogg'd him hither, and deſigns hereafter to make him pay for his Treachery. Madam, I have conſider'd on't, and will do my beſt endeavour to ſerve you; pray follow me ſoftly, I'me ſure he's not far off.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Believe a man when he ſwears? No, I'de believe the Devil ſooner, if he ſhou'd take a Ghoſtly Oath for Reformation.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: And will you Marry me, as Got pleſs you? will you always have Loves and Fidelities indeed?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Oh! will I live? will I be happy? prithee do not doubt me.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: I fow my heart does ſo tremble and peat, and her was ſo aſham'd.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Of what, my Dear? there is no cauſe.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Oh! there is crete Cauſes; for when firginities is gone, what will pecome of my poor Souls, look you?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Thy Soul! why, it ſhall be exchang'd for mine, and, happy we, ſhall by the Tranſmigration be Immortal.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: I ſwear you are fery leud mans to tempt me thus.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: I ſwear you are more cruel to deny me thus.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Oh! Heav'ns! but her was afraid 'tis grievous ſins.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: 'Pſhaw, 'pſhaw, a Sin! no, no, a Trifle, no more than telling a lye, a Venial Error. Gad I muſt make haſte, for if ſhe get once into a Religious vein, the Devil can't retrieve her. Come, come dear creature, delay is death to me.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Well, get you to that ped there, I'le go and diſpoſe Rachels out of the way, and then if you will be ſo unnaturals.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Do not believe I will. Go fly then with all the Wings of Love, for I ſhall wait thee with impatience.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Alas poor fools, her ſhall return too ſoon if her knew all. Now for the reſt of tricks and projects, and then Winny ſhall laugh, and take revenges of dull fellows, that loſe Pleſſings, and Critical Minutes, and Love-ſeaſons.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
Conſent adds as much to the Joys of Love as Beauty; 'tis the life, the ſoul of Enjoyment, when a dear-bought Amour, by talking, toyling, ſweating and ſtrugling diminiſhes half the pleaſure; and is juſt like one that
rides a tedious Journey upon a damn'd trotting Horſe, to poſſeſs an inconſiderable profit, not worth a quarter of his pains. She ſtays long, pray heav'n ſhe does not fall into a Fit of Religion agen, that's all my fear.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: within. — There's a Room lock't; by Mars I'le ſee what's there.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Hark! what noiſe is that? a plague on her trifling; if ſhe'de come and lock the door, we ſhou'd be ſafe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I'le hear no Excuſes, either let me ſearch fairly, or I'le ſend for my Lord Chief Juſtices Warrant.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Was ever poor Woman ſo diſtreſs'd? if I had ſtaid a minute longer in that room, he had certainly found me, for 'tis unfurniſh'd, and has no place of ſhelter. Where I am, I know not, nor what way to eſcape. Oh! for a favourable Window now, but one Story high, opening into a heav'nly Garden; I'de venture a Leg or an Arm with all my heart: Hark! he's coming, oh! whither ſhall I run. — Ha, what's here a bed? I think 'tis ſo; I'le wrap my ſelf in the Bed-cloaths, it may be ſome obliging Deity will pity me, and caſt a miſt before his Eyes.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: She keeps her word I ſee.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Ah! what's here a Man. Bened. goes to embrace her, ſhe ſhrieks and ſtarts back. Pray Sir, let me go, I am not the perſon you expect. Here the Bed is drawn up. What's here a Cheſt? I'le get in here, it may be this may ſecure me. Gets into the Cheſt.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Search you that Cabin, Sir Walter, whilſt I go in here and ſound yonder Sugar-Cheſt.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Hah! that's a mans voice, ſome-body is coming in hither ſure; but, by way of prevention, I'le go and bolt the door. How now! what a Devil is the meaning of this? where's the Floor? I believe the Devil is building, and has taken it away to ſupply his Domeſtick occaſions.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Jealouſie, like ſickneſs, is ever forming monſtrous fancies: Pray what have you found now? wou'd he had her, for I hate her for that Traytor Wilding's ſake. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: She Scuds before the Wind now, but I ſhall weather her anon: How now? what have we here a bed, and hanging in the Air by Geometry?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: My Nieces bed, Sir, made after the manner of a Welſh Hamock; I believe ſhe's in it too, you had beſt be rude now, and diſturb her.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hamock? why how the Devil can ſhe get into it? Oons can ſhe fly?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: No, Sir, and yet make uſe of it when ſhe has occaſion.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come, come, I'le ſearch, I'le ſee who's there. — Well, what News, Sir Walter?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: News! rare News, bleſſed News; why I have found 'em at laſt; there has been hopeful doings yonder behind the Hangings.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Between whom?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Ev'n Townly and your bleſſed Wife; they have been Communicating, it ſeems, for your good, Captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Oh Dog! oh Raſcal! ſteer me to him quickly — 'Sbud I'le flea him as I wou'd do an Eel.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: I can but laugh to think how demurely, how ſneakingly the Rogue ſtood up in the corner among the Cobwebs.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A Pox, bring me to him; do that; let me ſee him.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: So this will be ſome revenge upon her however. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: They are ſecur'd, and I'le ſhew thee the place; but I'le not be ſeen in perſon, for a private reaſon, beſt known to my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Nor I neither, though I wiſh her the puniſhment ſhe deſerves; I'le not be acceſſary. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I care not, away, Port hard, and put the Keel a-Weather; away, ſcowr.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: So, now I hope Fortune will ſmile upon me.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: 'Sdeath here's a whole Troop coming, and Wilding amongſt 'em; is there no way to eſcape?

div.stage: Enter Sir Walter, Wilding, Winifrid, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; there in that hanging-bed, ſay'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Yes, I fow in Altitudes and Expectations of Win • y's company's; Alas! poor Shentleman's.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: How Benedick?

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Cood morrows, cood Sir, methinks Loves, and Paſſions, and kind Pedfellows makes her look fery pale and wan, cood Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: This comes of Whoring, Benedick; this comes of Whoring.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How? is ſhe angry, ſay'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: I ſhall be angry, Sir, if you purſue this humour; but for thee, I'le only give thee this Curſe, may Pride, Pox, and Poverty poſſeſs thee till thou art nauſeous to thy own Sex, and contemptible to ours.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Ah, ſay your prayers petter, and chuſe pleſſed minutes and opportunities, you never elſe will win fair Ladies, upon my Souls, look you.

div.stage: Enter Captain and Townly fighting, Millicent Mask't, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Udſo, the Porpoiſe appears now, cheer up my hearts, here's a Storm a coming. So, Captain, you have found 'em I ſee. Parting 'em.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Found who, Sir? what mean you, Sir, Hoh?

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Mean, Sir, hoh? I mean you're a Cuckold, Sir; what a Pox ſhou'd I mean?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: With your favour, Sir, I ever give precedence to one of your Quality; you are a Knight, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: But my Wife is no ſuch Strumpet, Sir, to follow a man about the Town, Sir; Ha, ha, ha. Nay, Madam, you muſt not leave us, faith.
sp.stage: She's going, and he holds her.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, faith Madam, you muſt not leave us, you muſt unvail firſt; yours is a face, the Gentleman may know if he looks twice upon't.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I have had the Honour to ſee her: — What's here? what my Wife!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, no, a Strumpet, a Quean, that follows every man, Ha, ha; ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: My Spouſe! oh! Impudent! oh! Salacious Varlet! Jilt! Jeſabel! let me come to her.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Pray hear me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ay, pray hear him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Yes, you're a precious fellow to be heard, Sir: Oh, Raſcal, did you not ſwear by Gog, and Magog, and two or three Devils more, never to Violate the Perſon of my Wife.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Nor have I, Sir, upon my faith.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: This is my time to eſcape, if ever, and I ſee I muſt make uſe of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: And did I not for this reaſon read her o're, as it were a Lecture to thee? nay, there's ne're a Wart nor a Mole about her but I deſcrib'd, like a Son of a Whore as I was.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: I confeſs it, Sir, and my Fidelity both to her and you, I hope, has been apparent.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ay, ay, behind the Hangings very apparent indeed. Well, ſince this is the fate of Wiving; 'Sbud, for the future, I'le ev'n revenge my ſelf in the ſame manner; I have two Whores that lye yonder at Wapping, they are well waſh't, and tallow'd, and want only Rigging: by Mars I'le board 'em to night.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: What, both, Sir? both I beſeech you, ſpare one till to morrow. Peeping out of the Cheſt.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: My Wife here too, and conceal'd in the Sugar-Cheſt.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Shall not I have the Honour to warm their Night-Cloaths, or untye their Shooes, Sir? a poor Caſt Saylor of yours that wants employment.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, Miſtreſs, you are Boarded already, it ſeems by a new Officer there, and no doubt but he has giv'n thee Preſs-money.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Not yet, Sir; I am not prepar'd; I am not Waſh't nor Tallow'd, as your two Whores are at Wapping.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Plague on her, the Jade has got the Wind on me.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Behaving your ſelf ſo honourably towards me, cou'd you not forbear being Jealous, Sir? nay, and of Mr. Townly too, when had not his Intrigue with my Lady Millicent a little free'd me, Lord, what a Storm poor I ſhou'd have ſuffer'd under your boiſterous imagination.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Thou notorious Varlet, did not I poſitively enjoyn thee to rules of modeſty, and not to touch any thing bare above her ankle, hah? Hold up your hand; art thou Guilty, or not Guilty? hah?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Not Guilty, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: Well, though I know thou lyeſt, a Pox take thee, I will believe thee, becauſe 'tis for my quiet; but I will fight with thee too, becauſe it is for my honour; make thee beg thy life, and afterwards kill thee to ſatisfie my revenge; for thou haſt, I vehemently ſuſpect, made me a double Cuckold both in Wife and Miſtreſs, and therefore double ſhall be the puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nay, it ſhall be Treble, for I'le have a ſnack of him, by Mars.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: So I ſhall be cut into ſteakes ſure, and fry'd for their Suppers: Look, Gentlemen, pray no more words on't; as far as my Sword can go, 'tis heartily at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Sir Walt.
sp.p: When this is done, I'le bid farewell to this damn'd debauch'd Town; for my part, I'le ſcowr down to Lancaſhire and reap my Barley.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And I'le to Sea agen, I and my Jolly Crew.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: Whores and all, Sir?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, Buttock, Whores and all; there will I Conquer ſome flouriſhing Iſland, where I will plant a Colony, live out the reſt of my days merrily, and defie the Devil and Fortune.

sp.speaker: Livia.
sp.p: And I, poor melancholy Widow, will devote my ſelf to my Cloſet, and ſpend the reſt of my days in Prayers and Contemplations.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: And that is fery ſollitary livings and recreations, upon my ſoul is it, look you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Not to hear my defence, is barbarous.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: 'Tis Juſtice when the wrong's ſo palpable.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Your humour makes 'em ſo, although they are not.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: You are rude, pray keep your way.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: There's no ſuch Pride as Womans!

lg.l: The Ambitious Stateſman gay, and fond of Rule,
The Witleſs Courtier, and the Upſtart Fool

sp.p: had never half this Vanity; yet you ſhall ſee your Error. Heark, Sir! did you tell this Lady I was a Servant to Madam Livia there. To Townly.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: So, here's another Thunderbolt: A Pox on my Lying tongue, it will be my ruine one time or other. Aſide.
Why, faith Tom, to deal freely with thee, I confeſs I did tell her ſome ſuch buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Then, Sir, you are a Raſeal, and follow me.

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Not a foot, by this light I will not fight with thee, Tom, before Supper: But to put an end to the buſineſs.
Madam, what I told you was a damn'd Lye, and there is no truth in me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: That's not enough, Sir: did ever I ſpeak to thee of that Lady?

sp.speaker: Townly.
sp.p: Never, never, the Devil take me if thou didſt.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Now, Madam, what ſatisfaction muſt I expect?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: A man of Honour will be contented with what's reaſonable: there's my hand.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Heart and Lip too, or elſe the Article's not Seal'd.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p: Beſides, if you love me, 'twill be the eaſier to pardon.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I ſwear I love thee; but this haughty humour, this Cloud that ſhades the Sun of Perfection, does ſomewhat cool my paſſion: for believe me, Madam, and let your Sex all heed this Obſervation.

lg.l: Fools may love Pride, and a coy face adore;
Juſt Spaniel-like, though beaten, cringe the more.
To ſuch be proud and vain, but ſhun th' Offence,
If you wou'd e're attract a man of Sence.
Pride hinders there the Joys his Love wou'd bring,
As Storms and Froſts keep back the kindly Spring.

div.head: EPILOGUE ſpoken by a New ACTRESS.

lg.l: SInce Wit and Merit ne're can have the Grace,
To make you Pleaders in the Poets Caſe;
Nor this Collation gratefully to take,
Who knows but you may do it for my ſake:
For though in vain men for your favour ſue,
We Women often have a trick will do:
And therefore I am ſent here to engage
Friends to his ſide, and calm the Criticks rage.
If I ſhould fail, he would be apt to ſay
That I was in the fault, I damn'd his Play.
I that till now ne're ſo expos'd have bin;
Nay, and if hiſs'd, will never Act agen.
Then blaſt not, Sirs, the bloſſome in its prime,
Pray let me not be damn'd before my time;
I never bubbled ye, ne're made a League,
And after Jilted ye with falſe Intrigue;
Ne're balk'd your Paſſion with Sham • (female) Plots,
Your Pocket's pickt, or ſtole your lac'd Crevats;
Beſides, with your Opinion too I'me bleſs'd,
I'le take't on my Salvation I'me no Prieſt:
Nor did Religion e're my brains controul;
I am like you, of none, upon my Soul.
Great Intereſt to me the Golden Shore is,
Intereſt that makes you Fools, and Whiggs and Tories:
'Tis that obliges me with kind behaviour,
For th' Poet humbly ſue to get your favour.
I could command, but that's not yet my due,
Nor will not be (perhaps) this year or two.
But if you fail, look you your ground maintain,
For there will come a time when I ſhall raign.
A time will come, when Chloris ſhall be haunted,
Then all your Joys and Raptures ſhall be ſcanted,
And what you long wiſh for, ſhall ne're be granted.
